R6 was the reason I wanted a PC originally. but now this game just doesn't feel good to me anymore. I played on Xbox from 1.0 all the way to the end of year 6, I originally bought the game because I thought it would be an actual tactical shooter, but I grew to love it, but through the years the game has fallen from what it once was. Its now just an arcade shooter to me. There's no more realism, team play has gone to dogshit, and Gadgets that belong in sci-fi movies. In my opinion the game has been in a steady decline since chimera, but im still recommending this game. Because I started playing when I was 14 and I'm now 20 and even with the game being bad in my opinion some one new might find this game fun. Also they should remove Clancy's name from this game. Because this is not Rainbow Six game in all its aspects, beside the name

Don't recommend the game. As I am writing this review, this is my most played game on steam. I have many issues with the game that still have yet to change. The game's fights are often really fun and the pace of the game has been really smooth and addicting. The issues are outside the game and its management:

-Other players/the community is often toxic towards each other. In every competitive ranked match I have had to deal with people purposefully throwing the game or killing their own teammates on purpose. Ive had several matches where players abused glitches and bugs in the system to get me and other teammates banned from matchmaking. Reporting players takes forever to get a result and either way I still have to pay a 30 minute matchmaking ban because of the player that abused the glitch.

-Paywalls... every season a new character releases and is only available to those who buy the battle pass for the first month or so of every season. And if you did end up waiting for your turn to get the character, you still have to play an outrageous amount of hours to just get enough in-game currency to buy the character.

-Constantly changing meta... every update to the game changes the meta in some big way. They are always changing recoil on guns and their fire rates so much so that its not easy to get used to anything. On top of the behind the scenes changes and the recoils, they change what attachments are available for specific guns so often that your loadout has to change.

-Bugs in the game take forever to get fixed and even then, they often fix a bug and another bug comes up. For a long time there could be just a simple issue that for some reason forces your gun to have a certain attachment when you are a specific character and just messes with your usual aiming practices.

-Unable to find a balance... The game is unable to find a balance and the balance is so often swayed completely by every season. I wish they could just at least postpone a season to focus on the balancing issues they have at hand.

-Ignoring player/community requests... A little story has to start with a character they added called Blackbeard. The character has the ability to attach a shield to his gun in order to shield his head from headshots. In this game, the headshots are what matters as they are all 1 shot kills and its how fights go. This character was a disruption to the meta for a LONG time and they never changed the character until they eventually made the shield only able to withstand about 1 or 2 bullets and therefor now is a pointless character they should have just removed or redid his ability.

Best game ever. This game is an artwork that has implemented brain damage and soul-grabbing jinns into my head. I still remembered the day I purchased this which was the best decision of my life! It was like my full consciousness to be put to 100% of the left brain cells that I have. Depression raided my brain the day I played this cool cool game. Every nerf and every buff did not really affect me but affected the community. Developers had never really thought of listening to the people that actually played this game but only listened to higher-ups. It is truly crazy how racist this game is, not only it restricted some skins not to be given to certain races but just to be given some very epic helmets for the operators that I barely used. Not only just that it had affected how my life worked and relationships to only decline every offer of human connection in order to sacrifice my life to this epic game. This game is truly a drug for the people who are really attached and intrusive it felt like it was a white torture room and the only tunnel vision for living was to play this game. Escaping from the addiction of playing this game was one of the best decisions of my life and only just to transfer to an epic game called VALORANT. It really had me punishing myself in order to feel that light once more in my entire life, feeling the restrain of my brain due to this awesome game affected my long road to life. Now that I packed a black ice while writing this journal of the affect of Rainbow Six Siege on my life I truly apologize but never really deep-inside.

Great franchise that was ahead of its time, a shining superb tactical shooter that had little competition. Now this part in particular is terrible in almost everything. Poor balance, ugly gun physics that are neither realistic nor fun, jonky controls and unmemorizable maps. A lack of truly interesting operators, instead this game shoves a ""new"" overpowered transgender/minority guy (or gal whatever) into your face for a huge price every month. And they nerf it with time, as they do with basically everything, starting with operator abilities and gadgets to weapons and amount of ammo/grenades. Instead of giving us quality of life updates and bug/netcode fixes, they do cosmetic reworks that no one asked about. Jeez.

Ubisoft is scum. They make you connect to their own platform to launch the game and all it does is add a layer of headaches and technical issues that I don't experience when playing all of my other online steam games. Sometimes it can take a good 20 minutes or more of restarts before my friends and I can actually get into the same party and play. in 2022, for a 7 year old game, this is absurd. Just today out of nowhere the game asked me to initiate a two step security authentication where ubisoft asked for my name, email, and cell phone number. Why do I need to give you this to play a video game i've already paid for and have been playing for years?

Overall, It's a fun game when you can get it working, and I can appreciate that ubisoft does continue to add to it, but as a company ubisoft is turning into EA and i don't like supporting their practices.

One more thing to mention, I haven't had too many issues with cheaters, but accidental and intentional team killing has happened, which begs the question; WHY ISN'T REVERSE FRIENDLY FIRE ON BY DEFAULT? I don't understand the logic in letting someone kill a teammate first and then they only get penalized if they do it a second time. If i'm the person who got killed, why should I pay for someone else's idiocy, especially if that person was intentionally being a jerk? Why shouldn't they be punished immediately?  Reverse friendly fire is a great mechanic, but it would make a hell of a lot more sense if it was always on.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Right in the game's menu, I noticed that it doesn't recognize my mouse settings. Why? Simply a small query of the Windows mouse setting would fix this… uff, directly uninstalled again. The primary mouse button is not recognized and can't be changed within the game.

External programs that can set the mouse buttons don't help either. Although the change of keys is recognized, the game itself says that its internal settings are ALSO used. This results in the following action when the primary button is clicked: both the primary and secondary mouse buttons are registered when clicked. Why? It works for good games...

For anyone who's wondering, what's his problem? Try to put yourself in our situation. Change the primary key in the settings of your operating system (or your mouse driver). Operate your PC like this – that's how we feel when the program doesn't recognize the switch.

The core gameplay is obviously good, given my hours played. The simplest way to describe Siege's downsides would be a great core game with really poor execution in every adjacent social system.

Rampant:

- Team-killing
- Racism
- Cheating

Report someone for racism? Nothing usually comes of it. It happens a lot, surprise, some people are racist or want a reaction, usually both. You can check back a few weeks later, they won't be banned. You'll get in a match and people will start screaming the N word, you mute and report them, nothing happens. Then there are trolls. If you get stuck in a low rank, it's hard to climb out because every other game there's be the one guy team-killing you or others. Report them, check their account activity, nothing ever happens. 

You regularly encounter cheaters. This isn't theoretical, since you'll occasionally have your rank adjusted with a notification saying you faced a cheater who was later detected. That one thing, they sort of got right, but clearly they're not doing rigorous server-side validation to prevent cheating. I watched a video in the past week where a defender was able to go grab the defuser from an attack and plant it (something only attackers should be able to do) for defusing (win). This and many other ridiculous cheats you see (see: VarsityGaming on YouTube) regularly could very often obviously be detected and prevented proactively by simply doing good back-end validation of what should and shouldn't be possible.

Then there's the horrible social system you're forced to use for any group play: UPlay. Instead of just being able to invite a favorable teammate to a party through simple in-game means or tried & tested Steam, you need to press Shift+F2 to pull up this Ubisoft social system overlay menu, UPlay, and it is always bugged. 90% of the time I have added people, either one or both of us have needed to restart the game to see the friend request or party invite or whatever. Even log time friends can rarely invite / join each-other without a restart. For years, Ubisoft hasn't bothered to fix this sad broken system.

Alternatively there's the option to "Stay team", but even that system is broken and distrusted. "Stay team?" "It never works, let's make a party" (get ready to restart your game, usually).

Sept 11, 2022 update
There are tons of hackers in casual play. I'm now finding at least 2 per match. Why would I play any game mode more competitive (like unranked / ranked) if these hackers are ruining quick play.

Posted before  Sept 6th 2022 update

I've always liked Siege. Started on console, got tired of the mouse-adapters everyone was using. Went to PC and in every lobby, there's 1 hacker team killing everyone then killing the entire enemy team alone (I'm guessing for clips). 
This is all in quick-play, by the way. I haven't even tried unranked / ranked in years.

Then there's team killers. Picked their op? Dead. Hopefully it's a solo queue, because if not, you're dying by each friend of theirs for every round. If you think about it, you're penalized for getting team killed. Since you can't play, and they receive no penalty, esp if their friends continue this tking each round.
Group-queued team killing strikes should be a thing. A group-queued together that gets 2 team kills should be kicked, end of story.

I'd advise to only play quick play, so that way you don't actually lose anything from hackers.

I was starting to enjoy the game, but then all of a sudden, Ubisoft and their horrible anti-cheat system decided to place a perma-ban on me for apparently "cheating" when I never did. I tried my best to cooperate with Ubisoft Support, but they denied every single appeal I gave them. After that, I took it to reddit to complain about Ubisoft Support, I even provided video evidence to prove I didn't cheat on the matches I played. And guess what happened to the post less than 24 hours later. 
It got removed by the mods of the subreddit. Doesn't surprise me though, the mods are Ubisoft employees. Can't believe I'm being silenced over there.

Currently waiting on BattlEye to respond since Ubisoft redirected me to them, but they probably will ignore me anyway. 

My final review of this game:
Don't buy this game, don't support the horrible and greedy company behind it. I would seriously place a lawsuit if I had time and money since Support treated me like garbage.

Connection terminated. I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth, if you still even remember that name, But I'm afraid you've been misinformed. You are not here to receive a gift, nor have you been called here by the individual you assume, although, you have indeed been called. You have all been called here, into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune. A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach, but you will never find them. None of you will. This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you, although there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be. I am remaining as well. I am nearby. This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should.

And to you monsters trapped in the corridors, be still and give up your spirits. They don't belong to you. For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps more waiting for you after the smoke clears. Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole, so don't keep the devil waiting, old friend.

My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up into their arms the way you lifted others into yours, and then, what became of you. I should have known you wouldn't be content to disappear, not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now. It's time to rest - for you, and for those you have carried in your arms.

This ends for all of us.

End communication.

Constant game ruining bugs and frustrations not even related to gameplay itself. Even while typing up this reply I had an Ubisoft window pop up and interrupt me from writing. That applies to the in-game menu as well. You get backed out of the settings any time your squad leader queues for a match, the round starts, the prep phase ends, or the wind blows. The last month I have had to restart after every ranked match. If I don't restart, I will disconnect from the game servers and freeze for 9 seconds out of every 10. I'm not even going to list all of the gameplay related bugs like rubberbanding and clientside collision. When I am able to play a full match, a number of my lobbies have blatant cheaters in them. I wouldn't recommend this game to my worst enemy. It should be banned under the Geneva Convention as a form of torture.

One word. Ubisoft. When I purchased this game it was *fine*. But I had issues with even accessing it because Ubisoft will just take away access to your game, they don't have good servers, they rely on micro transactions at every corner as well. And that was when I got the game. It has gotten worse and the gameplay is no longer appealing or something anyone would probably wanna seek out in 2022. It is supposed to be a tactical team shooter but for some odd reason this game that used to be about precise shooting, checking cameras, making smart uses of your utility all went out the window for lazers, big explosions and traps that take no effort. The game is an unbalanced mess and characters are absolutely all over the place. They changed the user interface for the game and it is just atrocious to look at. It is gross, loud and large (loud referring to it being like in your face). The community is just racist, sexist, homophobic, transphobic and toxic. Nothing to do with the community is worth talking about. Now I mentioned earlier how they don't let people keep access to their game and I will explain. I bought the game on the Epic Launcher and it never let me install it on there anyways so I played through Ubisoft Connect. The game just refunded itself after about 4 months but it never gave me money back and I had to rebuy the game for no reason. I hate this game now and I hate Ubisoft.

so

I feel pretty comfortable saying that this game is always getting worse, and it will continue to get worse. Devs make bad decisions which make the game less fun and more stale feeling every year for returning players. Battle pass in Y7S2 is an all time low (i say after not playing this for the previous 4 seasons) ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Now as for new players i do think there is fun to be had here if you have friends, like i said earlier. I finally came back after a 4 season away and the only reason i did was because I had friends to play with. So if you got some buddies and you dont mind the total fucking slog that is learning this god forsaken game before your brains turn to mush then hop on in.

Lastly I'll say that while my friends got me to play again, the thing that is keeping me around (at least for now) is that Siege is the only game that can give me that rush from clutching a round, or hitting a crazy flick, or one tapping some numb nuts. There really is literally no game that feels like siege does. Every time I try another comp shooter, I just can't stick with it for long, but I guess there is a reason that I have that many hours in this game. oh well

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

My father smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, "If you ever want to see your children graduate, you have to stop immediately.". Tears welled up in his eyes when he realised exactly what was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your father put us through.". I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it because this game gave me cancer anyway.

DISAPPOINTING:

I've played siege since it first game out, first on Xbox and now steam. My account was recently suspended for "botting" despite the fact that I have never used a botting software. I contacted Ubisoft to see if they can review this action as it was clear to me a mistake had been made. Ubisoft said they were unable to review it and couldn't give me any details on my ban as it would "compromise the integrity of our internal systems".

I was very disappointed that I couldn't even get a review from Ubisoft "support" into the matter after all I was a dedicated member of the community for a long time.

Great game, would play again.

There's a reason I have so many hours in this game but not more than 20+ hours spent over the last 3 years of its' lifetime. The devs at Ubisoft would rather rework and (IMO) destroy every classic map that this game had. They had a vision to eventually have 100+ operators but cut the quarterly Seasonal operator additions from 2 to 1 (also reusing old weapons instead of adding new ones as they had with all new ops at one point) in order to work on gameplay and map changes that mostly (again IMO) weren't needed at all. The devs pander to the pro community because that's where the money is and this ideology led them to completely change the game rules from casual and solid ranked (classic) Siege to a abominable mix of pro-rules (operator ban and map pick phases and 2 round defense/attack swaps) that really just muddled the whole game for me. If you didn't play this game the first 3 years (arguably 2 years) then you missed out on the best of what Siege had to offer and it is now a (pro-league centered) shell of its former glory.

Fun game! I enjoy it as much as I enjoy smash bros. I love the idea of tactical warfare instead of just "run and shoot anything that moves." because you actually have to think about what your opponent is going to do. So many people go into this game thinking they can just easily win it by shooting things and then they end up blowing up to a Kapkan trap or they get crushed by a Frost Mat. Thank God you actually need more than an IQ of 2 to play this game effectively.

If you want a good relaxing tactical fps, then this may not be what your looking for. Siege is a game renowned for being tactical and brutal, and it definitely lives up to expectations. With every match being a test of skill, each round taking place in a different part of the map. You may be on offence waiting a solid minute to rush in and blow stuff up or you may a defenders, building the best defence you can in the short time given. These competitive matches can take a rather long time to end some ranging into 30+ minutes and others into 15min. 

The players like most fps are either a joy to play with or someone you would rather not spend your time listening to. Thanks to their being friendly fire or a mute option you can opt for peace and ignore, or shoot them in the face to escalate the problem starting a not not very uncommon miniature war. although the player you just erased from the round can push a button after being killed stopping you from shooting them while hurling insults.

As you start your first match in siege you will be thrown into a map with a bunch of new players, and most likely a Smurf account. The round starts and you run off only to get slaughtered by someone pixel peeking a hallway. This is the moment you realize siege is a rather slow game with long matches spanning minutes of slow and steady tactics and teamwork, with short matches barely reaching the depth nor the time of a skilled vet and his team. Although that probably wont be your first match. One of your first matches will most likely be a Smurf slaughtering your team, in a rather fast pace then proceeding to write EZ in the chat.

All in all siege is a game that requires a lot of time to get good at, a couple friends to make it fun, and a temper that is hopefully not short.

It was a great game, but the balance team ruins it. Never have I ever played a game where I dread getting new patches and have to watch the game slowly get worse. The dev's make bad changes based off of their win delta chart alone without thinking about the in game context. The buffs and nerfs are are seemingly randomly selected just to boost or lower win rates, again without taking into consideration why the operator is over/underperforming.

The matches don't last long enough, casual play gives you so little time to prep as a defender and then regardless of which side you're on everyone will rush the objective. Why? Idk this isn't Call of Duty but then again this is more toxic. Yeah, go play S&D and if you accidentally kill a teammate bc an enemy was there you'll have words but we'll move on bc we are trying to get that W. But Siege? F#$% no, Accidentally shoot your Kapkan bc you thought he was the enemy Fuze and it's like you ATF'd his dog. They'll throw the game just to get revenge. GR: wildlands multi was better because there was time to think, prep, feel out the situation,go fast then slow then rush again, etc. Wish Ubi stuck with that in Siege at least. 

P.S. Ranked might be different but since it takes so long to unlock it who cares.

As of right now, the game is moving in a way that makes it hard for new players with so many abilities and things to adapt to It's hard to get on the train that has derailed a lot but seemingly manages to get back on the track. (btw I came from ps4 with a lot of hours in the game 859). I hate this game with a burning passion, but there's something about it that once you're on, you can't get off. If you are a competitive person like me who lives to compete in every aspect of life, this is perfect for you. There's a lot to learn and crazy mechanics to learn, but if you are here as someone who wants to have a good time, don't play at the end of the day. This is a competitive game, so even in a quick match, there will be try hards and if you think that's stupid then don't play it won't be for you. But if you are reading this and you have played but took a break for a year and want to come back, please do although the game seems weird with the new ops, it's still a great game. There's nothing wrong with the changes. I came back after two years, and already I'm back into it, and I'm happy to say that even though there are some things in this game that are op or under the standard, they get fixed and changed bottysoft is doing a good job but not good enough to be called their real name so take that as you will. In the end, there is no other game on the market like this, and I love that with a burning passion.

Aight, ima just start this review by saying that in someways to some people, this game sucks. A lot. After I explain why though, I will give my reasons why I think Siege is great and worth time for new players.

1. Community is toxic af. Nobody can play this game casually without at least one person getting upset at them or complaining about ranks. If you get PTSD from thinking about old CoD BO 2 lobbies or whatever was most toxic back in the days, you may want to automute everyone in the server.

2. "Siege is supposed to be realistic." I understand that that's what people wanted from this, they wanted a tactical fps that encouraged teamwork to maximize the results of operators working together. Like a mix of Overwatch and Arma I suppose. Since it started though, Siege's universe has strayed away from that path by a longshot, with holograms and light barriers and laser barriers, etc. and etc.

3. Of course where there's a game with some kind of tactical choices, whether it be weapons, characters, or something simple as attachments, someone somewhere is going to be angy about you not using what is clearly the best option to use. Like, using the shotgun on Doc instead of the MP5. I don't know if this mentality is still around, but I feel with how the community is, there's only a few options players can choose to not get flamed by someone for just wanting to play their way.

Now, with what I find are negatives of the game out of the way, time for what I see are the positives of people trying the game as a new player.

1. More new players = more casual atmosphere. The more new players join, the more we have a chance at keeping this game alive and keeping it have a good casual atmosphere where it's fine to be casual. We don't need to TK each other just cause we didn't do something right or we picked your main operator. Yelling at the new players for being bad will make them leave, which ultimately means the game's health is the player's responsibility to keep the game nice and to keep new players wanting to play.

2. Personally, idgaf about realism. If it's fun, I'll play it. Whatever realism Ubisoft wants to keep in their game is their priority that we have no control over. I for one, dropped trying to make the game be realistic when we got the one with holograms 4 years ago. And with throwing realism out the window, it allows more opportunities for the game and more ways for Ubi to keep adding new stuff to the game.

3. If you don't run into any people who care a wee bit too much about what people do, there's a whole lot of choices in gameplay customization to fit whatever your playstyle may be. You wanna be a classic kick in the door "FBI open up" style kind of player, Ash is the girl for you. Wanna anchor down and keep the site secure while helping teammates stay alive, Rook is the best guy to start off with. With 64 operators in the game and many more on the way. hopefully, there's bound to be at least one operator that people will enjoy.

So yes, I'm not one of the blind Ubi lovers that ignore all the downsides of a game, but I do think there is hope for it. The community may be toxic, there may be cheaters here and there, there may be a giant lack of realism for some parts of the game, but when the bullets start flying and the team comms are open (especially when playing with the homies) this game is, in my personal and humble opinion, really something special.



(Also final message to Ubi if this review ever graces the dev's line of sight, can we please get a buff for Sens' AR? I'm still able to pop off with it, but please, it's 9mm, not .50 bmg, tone down the recoil a smidge at least.)

[h1] A paid game disguised as a f2p [/h1] 

Over the years I have been playing this game less and less due to unnecessary changes by the devs every 3 months. An Operator that has a high pick rate? Nerf. An Operator that has low pick rate, let's forget about it until years later. The game didn't receive any new maps after 3 years, they just "redone" old maps to be more in meta but became worse. Also for the longest time new Operators didn't come with new guns they just gave them less "popular" guns from existing Operators.

In ranked maps and Operator bans are worthless since you will be always playing the same maps and the time and money you spent to buy Operators will get banned for the match. It also adds unnecessary waiting for the game to start. But for some reason this game is trying so hard to be "pro" league. Keep in mind that the casual players it's what keeping your game alive.

The shop is mega expensive this is why I titled as a f2p game in disguise because no matter how many hours you play and how many renown you hoard you wont have enough to buy 5% of things in the shop (yeah that's me). There are charms that are so small that costs the same as a brand new Operator (25k) that's insane. It's almost impossible to afford to give your Operators a new look since everything is mega expensive. Keep in mind that I buy Operators with renown also.

There are other issues that I could write but don't have the energy to do so. If you are a new player wondering if you should buy the game or not keep in mind that this game is not new player friendly. It has a very hard learning curve.

I'll be straight forward with this. While I do not recommend this game, I will still be playing it. Why? I have too much time in it to switch and it is still fun. When I first started playing, it was this new tactical shooter that was semi-realistic, and that is what really set it aside from the rest of the FPS's out there. It has strayed so far away from its roots, and what type of game that it was supposed to be. There are so many crazy abilities and operators that I don't see it being the same game that it once was. The devs sacrifice quality gameplay and realism for fairness between attackers and defenders. It is just unfortunate how it turned out. Maybe I would not like the game had it continued down its original path, but I guess I will never know. 

TLDR: Still fun but no longer the game it was supposed to be.

HOW TO MAKE METHAMPHETAMINE

Diluted HCl - also called Muriatic acid - can be obtained from hardware stores, in the pool section. NaOH - also called lye Ethyl Ether - aka Diethyl Ether - Et-0-Et - can be obtained from engine starting fluid, usually from a large supermarket. Look for one that says "high ethyl ether content," such as Prestone Ephedrine. The cottons in todays vicks nasle inhalers dont contain efed or pfed (ephedrin or psuedophedrin) but there are still lots of easy ways to get good ephed or pfed. pure ephedrin can be extracted out of it's plant matter. from a plant that can be bought at most garden stores. Or you can get pfed from decongestive pills like sudafed. Most people perfer to workwith pfed from pills rather than ephed from the plant. The important thing is that you must have pure pfed/ephed as any contaminants will ♥♥♥♥ up the molar ratio leaving you with over-reduced ♥♥♥♥ or under-reduced ♥♥♥♥. Or contaminants will jell durring basifying and gak up your product which will then be very hard to clean. So you want to find a pill that is nearly pure pfed hcl, or as close to pure as you can get. Also check the lable on your pills and see what inactive ingredients they contain. Inactive ingredients are things like binders and flavors. These you dont want and will remove when cleaning your pills but certain inactive ingredients are harder to remove then others. You dont want pills with a red coating. you dont want pills with a lot of cellose in them and you dont want pills with much wax. you also dont want pills that contain povidone. As a rule, if you have a two pills that contain the same amount of pfed hcl then take the smaller sized pill because it obviously has less binders and inactive ingredients. time released pillsa re usualy harder to work with because they have more binders and tend to get up durring the a/b stage. Also only buy pills that have pfed hcl as the only active ingredient. You first have to make ephedrine (which is sometimes sold as meth by itself) if you are selling. I would just make ephedrine on your own because its really cheap, so you have no reason to use the nasty stuff from the tap. Do things right. List of equipment: A glass eyedropper, Three small glass bottles with lids (approx. 3 oz., but not important)one should be marked at 1.5oz, use tape on the outside to mark it (you might want to label it as ether). One should be clear (and it can't be the marked one). A Pyrex dish (the meatloaf one is suggested) A glass quart jar, Sharp scissors, CLean rubber gloves, Coffee filters, A Measuring cup, Measuring spoons. Ethyl Ether: WARNING: Ethyl Ether is very flammable and is heavier than air. Do not use ethyl ether near flame or non-sparkless motors. It is also an anesthetic and can cause respiratory collapse if you inhale too much. Take the unmarked small bottle and spray starter fluid in it until it looks half-full. Then fill the rest of the way with water, cap the bottle and shake for 5 minutes. Let it sit for a minute or two, and tap the side to try and separate the clear upper layer. Then, draw off the top (ether) layer with the eyedropper, and throw away the lower (water) and cloudy layer. Place the ether in the marked container. Repeat this until you have about 1.5oz of ether. Put the cap on it, and put it in the freezer if you can. Rinse the other bottle and let it stand. Ethyl ether is very pungent. Even a small evaporated amount is quite noticeable. Pour 1/8 teaspoon of the lye crystals into the bottle of ephedrine and agitate. Do this carefully, as the mixture will become hot, and give off hydrogen gas and/or steam. H2 gas is explosive and lighter than air, avoid any flames as usual. Repeat this step until the mixture remains cloudy. This step neutralizes the HCl in the salt, leaving the insoluable free base (l-desoxyephedrine) again. Why do we do this? So that we can get rid of any water-soluble impurities. For 3 oz. bottles, this should take only 3 repetitions or so. Fill the bottle from step 5 up the rest of the way with ethyl ether. Cap the bottle, and agitate for about 8 minutes. It is very important to expose every molecule of the free-base to the ether for as long as possible. This will cause the free base to dissolve into the ether (it -is- soluble in ether). Let the mixture settle. There will be a middle layer that is very thick. Tap the side of the bottle to get this layer as thing as possible. This is why this bottle should be clear. Remove the top (ether) layer with the eyedropper, being careful not to get any of the middle layer in it. Place the removed ether layer into a third bottle. Add to the third bottle enough water to fill it halfway and about 5 drops of muriatic acid. Cap it. Shake the bottle for 2 minutes. When it settles, remove the top layer and throw it away. The free base has now been bonded to the HCl again, forming a water soluble salt. This time we're getting rid of either-soluble impurities. Make sure to get rid of all the ether before going to step 11! If there is anything left from step 3, repeat the procedure with it. Evaporate the solution in the Pyrex dish on low heat. You can do this on the stove or nuke it in the microwave (be careful of splashing), but I have found that if you leave it on top of a hot-water heater (like the one that supplies hot water to your house) for about 2-3 days, the remaining crystals will be ephedrine HCl. If you microwave it, I suggest no more than 5-10s at one time. If it starts "popping", that means you have too little liquid left to microwave. You can put it under a bright (100W) lamp instead. Microwaving can result in uneven heating, anyway, this game is pretty fun with friends.

I wasted a thousand hours (if including the Test Server) on this game. Don't do the same mistake I did.
While the occasional Clutch, or Ace, or whatever thing that may happen, will give you the hit that you will probably crave and use as a justification for forcing yourself through the game. In reality, the majority of the gameplay can be anything from boring to rage-inducing. With one of the most toxic communities to date, one where, at the very least, every second match features someone shouting in Text or Voice Chat, don't expect to make any friends here besides the ones you already had.
Speaking of, yes, this game is more enjoyable with friends... But so is practically every multiplayer game. If you are gonna buy this game because "playing with friends is cool", please, consider other games before this one, especially because of how bad the servers are. They are rented Microsoft servers, and it shows, as playing with anyone outside your own country results in a massive ping advantage for those closer to the server. And no, there's no lag compensation. Someone could be peeking 0.2 seconds into the future and have killed you before you even know it.
And let's not forget cheaters. Despite this game using BattleEye, which is quite a penetrative Anti Cheat, there's still a lot of cheaters in Ranked. This makes practically every "competitive" gamemode unplayable.
Finally, the skill curve. Many games tend to have skill curves where you can tell a skilled player from a non-skilled player apart. I, and many friends, have noticed that nothing matters in R6S, you seemingly still get bodied with only a good match every so often. The K/D always stays under 1, and whether that is someone completely new to shooters, or someone with years of experience. It gets to the point where many have made the hypothesis that your success in R6S is dependant on your mood.

In short: Gameplay is unfun and only disguises itself as fun by giving you that "big hit" every few matches, people are toxic, there are better games to play with friends, ranked is busted due to cheaters, and there's a lack of a skill curve.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is the best and most unique first person shooter I have ever played, and I recommend it to anyone looking for an amazing game to play. When I first started playing, I could never understand why I dropped so many hours in this game, but after some time, I think I understand now. Rainbow six siege is a mirror image of your commitment, character, and what makes you, you. 
    Rainbow Six Siege is good because its a simple objective for both sides. A team must defuse a bomb or defend the bomb from being defused. but its within that simplicity where Siege shines it brightest, because beyond that simplicity lies a very in-depth, complex game.
    Siege has a large roster of characters and they all have an assortment of special gadgets and weapons. By using these characters, you can do anything you want with them. These operators can interact with the map in creative ways because the majority of maps have destructible walls and floors that allow you to create unique angles, clever strategies, and allow players to push themselves as far as they want to go.  
    Siege enables you to grow as a player because it punishes you for every mistake you make and rewards you for succeeding. This is the only game in my library that I desire to be good at because of this. With every death you learn something new, and every kill you get teaches whoever is on the receiving end a lesson. but that's only because the game has brutal consequences due to its lack of respawning. 
    With that being said, there is a lot to learn and experience while playing the game. Almost all the learning you do will come from the playerbase. The community has endless videos online showing incredible angles and gadget placements to help you get an edge on the enemy and gain the upper hand in any match. This is all thanks to Sieges mechanics. But its not just the mechanics of the game that make it good, but its how well the use of those mechanics are put to use by the players.
     I would also like to mention how well Ubisoft keeps the game in check. The game is updated frequently and keeps me coming back with excitement seeing how operators and metas change each season, and seeing what new things are brought to the table. There used to be major problems with bugs and glitches but I personally have not experienced anything unjustifiable recently. 
     In conclusion, if you are on the fence for getting this game, I recommend you try it out.

A very fun game except when you run into toxic players and hackers which use to only occur in ranked but now happens in quickmatch because this game breeds toxic players and Ubisoft made a somewhat smart change by banning phone numbers of banned players which is needed to play Ranked but this just means hackers are in quickmatch because they can just create a new account and hackers are still in Ranked because the anti-cheat sucks. 

But hey, if that hasn't turn you off the game, it's all good. You can play the game just fine, maybe find an operator you like that you can get a few kills with, just don't expect that operator to be good in 3 months when the new season comes out, their gun will have an absurd amount of recoil and their gadget will be completely different. That is unless their gun is an LMG and their gadget lets them heal all their teammates instantly and revive them self and have grenades as their secondary.

But look, there's still fun little things to do like going into a hiding spot and getting the drop on a completely oblivious person and having a laugh, that is if the map didn't secretly get patched and the spot was removed because it was so "gamebreaking". But look, maybe you get into a five stack with your friends and are just messing around in quickmatch and you occasionally shoot each other as a joke. You're not ruining the experience for anyone because you're all in the same party and having fun but then you finish your game and you have RFF for the rest of your life and so you have to learn to be a pacifist so you don't accidentally kill yourself because your teammate walked in front of you while you were shooting a camera.

Oh, I noticed you really enjoyed that map, there were some nice angles you could hold and some wacky run-outs annnnnnndddd it's gone. Completely different map, may as well have been set in a different country. Why? Well because of a small minority of players, known as pros, thought the map was too unbalanced and WAY too fun. I mean, who wants to have fun when playing a video game? Not those guys apparently. It's not like one of the very gamemodes this game offers is colloquially referred to as Casual or anything, who would ever call it Casual? This is a very serious fast-paced, team-based, tactical first person shooter with a separate gamemode called Ranked for players that want to get on leaderboards and play competitively.

I swear to the lord above, Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege has blessed me and my family with good fortune. Ever since my teammate Th3F0XF1nG3Rer had spoken in game chat and wished the worst upon me, I have pulled through my chemotherapy, my family had pulled through in their financial struggles, and I had finally gotten to touch some grass (even though I had been deathly allergic to the substance beforehand). A big shoutout to Th3F0XF1nG3Rer and his colleagues in that ranked match I had played, Rainbow Six Siege has changed my life, and allowed me to see things I had never thought possible for myself. I am a new me, I hope the same happens for all the players who have stumbled across this elo messiah. In the name of Allah the most gracious the most merciful. All the praise and thanks is for Allah, the Lord of mankind, jinn and everything that exists, and may the prayers and peace of Allah be upon the most honorable of all the Messengers, Mohamed. To our beloved Sheikh and able emir Abu Musab Abdul Wadud, may Allah keep him safe. May the peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be with you. I pray to Allah that my letter will find you in the best of spirits, moving from one victory to the next. We have received the glad tidings of your victories in the Islamic Maghreb which came to us here in the East like a gentle breeze, reminding us of the victories of our forbearers, and it made us, along with other Muslims, very happy. Rainbow six is very much recommended to people who like a realistic shooter with an operator, “character” selection style platform. It’s pretty good as a game and is setup in a way that makes you keep playing. Overall recommended.

It is unforgiving, and you're forced to learn quick or be very bored with the game. It's impossible to recommend R6 to any new player that doesn't have a lot of patience and a lot of spare time. If you're a solo player it's impossible. With friends it's possible, but you'll arguably have more fun in another game.

(sorry for the grammer) I have recently gotten into Rainbow 6 and haven't played much of ranked or unranked but I believe it's still a good fps game. The things that are good about this game is that tactical part of it. I love how you not only need good aim but good perception too! There many fps game that have the player use their senses but siege takes it a step forward and makes the player require to use their senses if they want to win by having the player be easy to kill whether or not its a stray pistol bullet or a 6'4 frenchie charging at you with a riot shield. This is still very hard for most people to do and requires a lot of practice but its so satisfying why you get a kill using your head. Perception is not only important in siege but your resources like your utility, the map, and importantly your team. Communicating with your team maybe the most important thing in siege and maybe makes the game unfun. Its hard to win when you solo queue and the community of siege is horrible, but when you play with friends its a lot of fun. The game can be played seriously or can be played like total dumb asses, committing the most stupid stuff with friends and having a blast. The balancing of this game is not the best and it may not be in it's best state but its has a special spot in my heart. I think more people should try this game out even with its flaws.

This game simply was doomed for its longevity from the very beginning. Ubisoft as everyone knows is a very terrible company that loves to implement pitch perfect examples of anti consumer practices into their products and maybe establish an esports scene that will inevitably lead to its slow and agonizing end. I used to love this game and I confidently say that this game holds a special place in my heart. I first played the game in beta on my cousin's xbox all the way back when I was still just a preteen. I got the game myself in operation black ice and played consistently all the way up until operation grim dawn. On console I have roughly 2,500 hours on xbox, (my name on xbox is the same as steam "TylerDoubleU". Look at it if you want to fact check me.) 

Set up for failure
This game was launched in a terrible state. Although it has been out for over half a decade you would think that problems that have persisted since launch would be solved, but unfortunately a lot of the problems are literally impossible to solve. The game's engine is the same engine that was intended for the Prince of Persia game on a console, the anti-cheat has never gotten better, servers have gotten better but are still poor, in order to actually play the game at its highest potential you need to unlock most of the operators which take over 200 hours of game time unless if you pay money, the balancing team's solutions to every single meta is to nerf the meta to the ground, and the game has straight up completely lost its identity of being a gritty realistic tactical competitive first person shooter. Almost all of these issues have been a massive problem for literally as long as I remember. I would strongly encourage anyone to be invested in a better title that just so happens to not be a Ubisoft title

Competition
As for competitive shooters rainbow six just does not even compete. There are too many problems fundamentally with the game in order to fully flourish as an esport and a competitive shooter. Quite honestly there are just other games that do what siege tries to do in extremely better execution. Counterstrike is a solid choice that has many factors on siege such as: a reliable anti-cheat, little to no bugs, good servers, community participation such as aim training maps, consistent gunplay, entertaining esports, and better map design. There are other exceptionally  superior options as well like something a little closer to siege valorant. 

Problems with high elo
In siege no matter the platform you play on you will always run into loss conditions that is straight up out of your control. On console it is mouse and keyboard users when you finally climb to the very top, and of course on PC its littered with cheaters closeted or not in both high elo and highly populated ranks. You simply can not climb to a high elo fairly and by the small chance that you do you will never be #1 because it is always a cheater or someone who exploits the next not fun meta. 

Nostalgia 
Don't get me wrong when siege works how it is supposed to it is the most fun I will ever have in a game. I plated it way too much as a early teenager and as a kid and even when I play now I still have that feeling every once in a while of trying my absolute hardest at getting better and reaching that rank that I have set as a goal for myself for the past 2 years. Unfortunately though I can't commit to this game even if it is as stable as when I consistently played this game. The only way they can recover this IP and make use of an extremely unique and fun idea is to make a sequel with better servers and an even better engine.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I appreciate:
• The main concept (a more “realistic” version of Overwatch, with gadgets replacing ultimates, and fast-paced rounds).
• The wide choice of operators, with enough different playstyles that the game cannot really get boring, since one can switch operators at every round.

I dislike:
• The wildly unrealistic handling of guns that makes no sense (shots are fired from the crosshair, recoil is always up regardless of the position of the gun, reloads can be interrupted any time).
• The randomness of maps (impossible to play one map for several dozens of rounds, to get to know it better).
• The lack of off-meta content (there is absolutely NO reason for anyone to use ironsights or semi-auto guns; only one playstyle works).

I hate:
• The microtransactions. Paying 60 EUR for this game isn’t enough, apparently.

I used to love this game. It united my friends and me for over 500 hours of gameplay. As for gameplay, the game has lost much of its original charm as a SWAT simulator. Careful planning and tactics have been replaced by what are ultimately now superpowers. In its early beginnings, most of the abilities and operators were somewhat grounded in reality. Now many of the characters feel more like knock-off marvel cops, as they litteraly "Kool-Aid man" through walls and punch with robotic arms. 

Add to the loss of realism the unfortunate reality that the game has been taken captive by Ubisoft's woke messaging. The company has spent three years subtly reworking maps to eliminate the presence of suicide bombers, drugs, and sex trafficking so that the maps can be played in china and pass their censors. Add to that the increased pandering to diversity inclusion as they explore its operators' sexuality and gender identity. 

The game is now unrecognizable from when it launched so many years ago. It is an unfortunate loss. I recommend that players who are seeking a SWAT experience instead spend their time on "Ready or Not."

It's long overdue that I write a review for my most played game.

	Let me start by saying that Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is the most captivating game I have ever played. The foundation of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is outstanding. The depth of gameplay is endless, especially with the consistent update schedule. The unique destruction and the adaptive dynamic sound system are revolutionary. The intricate information game tied in with the versatility of operators keeps you interested and thinking. The drive of competition and the thrill of clutches is an emotional rollercoaster you can't help but continue to ride. All of it makes for a unique, unforgettable experience.

	But does that mean I recommend you play Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege? Sadly, It doesn't, for both returning and new players. I do not recommend this game. It hurts me to say this because I love this game. First off, Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege emphasizes competition and team play. It's partially why this game is so great. So if you don't want to "sweat" or try your best all the time, this game is not for you. Unfortunately, Playing solo is horrific. Why is that? It falls on how people suck. This community is atrocious. I highly recommend you look elsewhere. When first writing this, I listed all the player types that were contributing to the deterioration of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege. That list is extremely long. It also doesn't put the best taste in my mouth. The thing is that those people aren't going to change. They will always be awful. The main issue is a lack of teamwork and cohesion among players. It's needed for this game to work,  and the community doesn't want it. You will get insulted and mocked relentlessly instead of helped or guided. Having a simple disagreement will turn into a full-out brawl of racial slurs. It's impossible to discuss anything with anyone. I think that it's insane that people can't be rational or reasonable. Arguably that's a requirement needed for holding a job, Which happens to be nonexistent in players. If you still want to play this game against my recommendations. It's a requirement to have someone who is already playing. Especially since Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege won't teach you a single thing about multiplayer. Not only that, it's paramount to have an entire squad of friends. It makes for a way better experience. 

	I haven't mentioned the Developers because they received enough hate and ill-willed criticism because of the failure of the community to be individuals and use any amount of brain power. Not to say I don't have criticism or suggestions. I don't want to be associated with the notion of #SaveSiege. Or be used as ammo for Keyboard Warriors to continue harassing the passionate development team. I'd rather discuss and deliberate what I think needs to get changed with people that can think for themselves.

	I hope the reputation system will alleviate players' temperaments and allow collaboration and cooperation to return to the player base. Sadly, it's a far stretch I doubt will come true. If you want to talk about Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege, I am always down for that. I'm addicted to Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege and can't stop playing. Thanks for taking the time to read my review of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege.

I thought moving platforms would make my experience with this game a little bit more bearable but it only made it worse. I've violated every article of the Geneva Convention in every possible way. I've shot, stabbed, gassed, poisoned and bonked thousands. I am what every war criminal in the Balkans imagines before they close their eyes at night. I was the last image in Slobodan Praljak's head before he drank cyanide in the courtroom. The simple uttering of my name made Oskar Dirlewanger uncomfortable in his big boy officer breeches.

You do not 'play this game casually'. You do not 'play for the community'. There is no community. When you discover the first griefing Frenchman in your lobby, you will realise what an utter waste of time this endeavour was, and how foolish you were to believe that this game would be even tolerable to play.

Half your time will be spent explaining to your squadmates how 'it was a headshot', and the other half will be spent observing Ela's asscheeks on your drone as she reinforces the objective.

The narrative behind Rainbow Six Siege is completely contorted and incomprehensible. It just convinces me that Ubisoft have no idea what the hell to do with this game anymore; I was especially convinced of this after seeing Sens, the newest operator, who has a dead albino porcupine sitting on their head. Really summarises the game after 6 years of constant updates which have only succeeded in making the game feel bloated and turned away thousands of casual players.

Want to play casual? Have fun getting killed by smurfs unable to play at their own skill level.
Want to play unranked? Have fun getting instantly beaned by a cheater four rounds in a row because you can't leave or risk getting banned.
Want to play ranked? Have fun trying to find a non-toxic squad who have enough patience to stick out with you in higher ranked lobbies (which are filled with cheaters, by the way).

Every time I spend money with this game I get disappointed. But that's actually because I do that when I'm usually more addicted to the game thus playing more and suffering more with its problems. 

The game itself is level & graphically well designed. Has a good community and almost does not suffer with cheaters compared to other games. This is a consequence of the game itself being paid, so before you start playing you have to spend some money in order to play.  That makes the game environment much more controlled which is a thing I find pleasant from this game.

The not so good thing is that double XP events are super uncommon and the grind in order to get a good amount of the operators from the game (even if you start with some) is tough. Seems like its this way so Ubi can make some extra profit out of it.

Also when you play the game a lot you're going to notice that there are some dumb stuff all around it, that could be easily fixed by ubi side but its just not fixed because of clear laziness. Stuff that use to work and stops working for obscure reasons etc. And stuff like the unability from Ubi employees to remove temporary sanctions (bans) from Unranked and Ranked matches due to abandon. Even when the abandon was caused by game/server's fault.

Besides that, I appreciate that ubi stills updates the game and add new content to it, but thats not something I wouldn't expect from a paid game.

At one point you could've called this a fun game, but the barrier for entry is now too great to really enjoy any aspect of it... No matter what Ubisoft tries, the skill floor will always ruin the fun of this game. Doesn't matter if you have 5 hours or [i]500[/i] hours, the other team is always better, or you get the bad site on a map (of which no good ones remain). It feels like the game is deliberately trying to ruin the day of everyone I play with, and we can all confidently say that we have not enjoyed any match of this game in a very long time.

The community itself is the problem, and there is no fix for that. The changes made in the past year or so to childproof the game (no more ranks shown, global chat off by default) conflict with their own goals of player safety, because you can still get in a match with a player you've blocked if someone else in your party [i]hasn't[/i].

I cannot recommend this game (or most games nowadays for the same reasons) to anyone outside of profession e-sports gamers, because that's all you'll find playing anymore. I play video games to have fun and enjoy my time away from more strenuous activities, not work even harder just to compete.

An exceptional tactical shooter. The graphics are not groundbreaking however fitting to the intended competitiveness of the game. The gameplay is in its' basis simple, however with the different operator's loadouts, stats and abilities, it offers a highly diverse and dynamic gameplay. The maps besides their astonishing details compliment the very core aspect of this game that all actions must be thought through and will always have consequences in one way or the other. It makes it immediatly obvious that team-coordination and -cooperation is key to a successful. But even if you have those things, things can always go wrong, whether it be because of the map, the competition or the circumstances. The lore I personally do not care about. Though I am unsure about the of recently more ambitious gameplay additions, I have no doubt that this is one of the most high-quality tactical shooters out there.

I really want to recommend this game, but there are some pretty big issues that need to be resolved if Ubisoft wants there to be a lasting future for this game. 

Pros: Great strategy game with some of the best feeling mechanics. I played this game extensively before getting a PC. It's insanely fun. The operators are unique and each provides a refreshing style of gameplay for the player. 

Cons: The game is dying, steadily, not rapidly. The game fell off and part of that is Ubisoft's fault in terms of marketing. Current players have no news tab or get any advertisements for new operators, events, etc. Just recently an event went public and no one knew of it until the day before. It's hard to keep the community wanting more if there is no news to provide hype for the game. With the community as toxic as it is, why would players want to stick around to play if there was nothing to look forward to? Another thing to add on; Operators are SO EXPENSIVE. They DO NOT require micro-transactions to own and play, I want to make that clear. But, there are so many operators now (64 at the time of this review) that you have no hope of getting all of them unless 1. You play every day and grind or 2. You buy them with money. Just for reference, you can get most of the operators for $40. Each time you unlock one, that price drops a little bit. So there is an incentive, but I think it's a ridiculous price for the characters. And no, I have not spent any money to buy operators on PC. I may have bought a season pass or two when I played on console in the glory days. 

Overall, it is a brilliant game, and I do like it. If you are willing to put up with toxicity and do some research as to when events and new season releases will come out, then get it, you'll have a blast once you get used to everything.

-huge variety of operators, each one feels pretty unique
-can be played sleathily or not, but stealth is best option
-most maps are pretty good
-you can play co-op or solo against bots which have 3 different difficulties(normal, hard, realistic) which is what I recommend if you don't care about people being assholes
-surprisingly isn't too much of a buggy mess considering it's a Ubisoft game

cons:
-horrifically toxic community, probably the worst one in all videogames. seriously, its impossible to get into a match of people where slurs and other horrific things aren't said
-while stealth is optional, it isn't recommended, so it can take awhile to get used to it if you don't play many stealth based games already
-it's made by Ubisoft

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I have tried Fornite.  PUBG.  Apex and Warzone.  Maybe I'll see if Valorant can save me, but I doubt it.  No matter what I try, nothing compares.  I might last a week or two, but I always come back to Siege.

No other game offers the highs of getting your first ace.  And no other game offers the blinding rage of getting spawn-peeked on the final round of a ranked match.

It's not perfect, and sometimes it seems like Ubisoft is actively trying to make it worse, but Siege on its worst day is still better than any other competitive FPS I've tried.

I downloaded this game thinking it was going to be easy. I am currently fleeing the country because of rainbow six siege. I will tell you the story of how this game caused my downfall. It all started the first day of me downloading this game. I got into the game, joined my friend, and we queued into a quick match. A good word to describe that match would be chaotic. Explosions happening every second, bullets flying by my head every which way. It was stressful to say the least. Though this caused me to have the want to get better. Skip 100 hours and I'm in an Un-ranked game and some guy I tk'd on accident says hes going to D-dos me. Now I didn't believe him, which I regret. He booted me off my internet and fried my router. I was pissed off so I called the police to get him arrested for what he did. When I called 911 I completely blanked. I didn't know what to say. They asked, "Sir... Are you okay". I quickly said "Yes, I was just prank calling, my bad". Now you might be wondering why I said I was prank calling. Well, the reason I said this is because I forgot the guys username and turned my PC off. After I said I prank called her she was not that happy. She started to go off on me saying how immature I was being and how I should never prank call anyone, especially 911. Before she could continue I hung up. 10 minutes go by and I hear a hard knock on my door. I quickly get up from my chair to go open the door. When I open the door 2 police officers are standing on my porch. Now I'm freaking out. I thought this was about the prank call. I ask why they are here and they say that the station got a call saying I was planning on blowing up the orphanage about 25 miles away from where I lived. If I am going to be honest, I started laughing because it was so random that I couldn't hold it in. The cops didn't laugh, they just looked at me asking if it was true. I quickly told them no while trying to be serious. They asked if they could search my house just in case. I said yes but told them to not break anything, because I have a lot of expensive items. After about 1 hour of them snooping around, 5 more cop cars pulled up. I was a bit confused so I walked outside and they told me to get on the ground with my hands up. I complied because I didn't feel like resisting. Now there is going to be a massive time skip so let me shorten the time in between. I was sentenced to 8 years in prison after they somehow found evidence of the whole orphanage explosion thing on my computer. I escaped prison after 2 years while there was a massive fight going on between guards and prisoners. Now I've been out of prison for a week and finally found a car to flee the country. Also, I'm assuming that the stupid D-dos kid hacked my computer as well and put fake plans of the orphanage thing on my PC and then called the cops. I don't know if this is true I'm still trying to figure that part out. But right now I'm half of the way to Mexico from New York. So hopefully by the end of this month, I'll make it to Mexico and finally be out of this god awful place. Anyways I say Rainbow Six Siege is a great game. I would give it a solid 5/5, so good job Ubisoft.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
