The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Pros:
1. Good events sometimes.
2. Good selection of different characters and abilities to use. Counter-play is fun.
3. Gun selection is pretty good. 

Flaws:
1. Player base is full of unfunny and annoying "people". You have to be on guard for team-killers.
2. Too much downtime in between rounds with unnecessarily long transitions.
3. No cross-progression and skins are overpriced. 
4. Occasional if not frequent bugs (dead audio or endless gunfire, black screen, etc).

Recommendation:
Get the game if you like tactical shooters. Only play with friends (you might get pissed with them but it's better than dealing with randoms).

I used to really like this game. However the devs at Ubisoft have been systematically ruining it. Over time, Rainbow has slowly turned into an arcade shooter. Probably because Ubi thinks it panders better to a younger audience, but the facts have consistently proven this wrong. Despite serious players and long time casual players constantly giving feedback on what we want and don't want, Ubisoft chooses to ignore them and do what they think will make it more popular. Not to mention, many of these changes have caused game breaking bugs, and they don't add anything worthwhile to the game. It's clear this game is dying. a few years ago, I would have suggested anyone who enjoys FPS games should buy Rainbow, but it's obvious the developers do not care what happens to this game anymore. Ubisoft is actively destroying it, because it makes them money. it's nothing more than a cash grab to them now.

So down below was a update earlier, and guess what? They managed to get it even worse!
Sadly most games are infested with cheaters using a Meastro camera as if it's a nuclear bomb, sadly due to Ubisofts policy you're forced to play or you will get banned for quite a while eventhough you've played against the same cheater before, in the past you could block them but with the amazing new privacy option this is no longer a option, great addition Ubisoft!

The launcher also loves to hijack your mouse when leaving the game or not letting you invite your friends, the best suprise it had for me was randomly invert all sound (issue doesn't pop up when ubisoft is closed).

This terrible state of the game is reinforced by the huge amount of content creators leaving the game for greener grass (aka a developer who doesn't release 200 euro of new skins instead of actual fixes).

===========================================================================

Ubisoft managed to bring a game enjoyed by many to a game hated by most.
Rainbow Six Siege was en still has the potential to be an amazing game, however the issues regarding the UPlay Connect, Anti Cheat and the overall stability (glitches and bugs) is ridiculous for a game of this age.

Sadly the game in it's current state hasn't aged like fine wine like other games in the series, Ubisoft is extermely focused on the monetisation of the game after the initial sale with a huge variety of skins surrounding popular pop-cultures and the ESports scene while neglecting the gameplay itself by pushing out content in the form of new operators to make it as difficult as possible to get into the game with the gigantic amount of gadgets and abilities you have to watch out for.

If you're a new player I sadly have to recommend you to either have a very thick skin and get through the terrible community and endless hours of suffering to get a hang of the game or try a different game in the hero shooter genre.

Players that have played this in the past will get suprised by the 180 change of direction the game has made, but will be able to get into it very quickly by the lack of innovation.

Hi, im Elegant and ive played since Velvet Shell in the first year (of SEVEN!) of siege. and the game has had a PLENTIFUL amount of Awful moments. Ive endeared it, raged, laughed, made jokes, been toxic myself and been in situations that make me think that they shouldve been banned, i have only 150ish hours on pc. but nearly god idk like 4k on Xbox between 2 accounts. I've put in the time and sweat. 

This game is hard. Dont let ppl tell you otherwise. The Community like i said is well established at certain strats and knowledge. You will die, a lot. You will hate the game, a lot. You will Love the game, sometimes when it works and you do something cool. The learning curve is so steep that Pros are always learning new angles and strats bc the nature of the game allows for full imagination to hold an Objective or to attack one, its one of the reasons ive always appreciated the loop of the game.

I recommend this game bc with it came literally my best friends that ive met irl and had the pleasure of knowing for 6 years now. The memories live with me, the rage lives with me. I understand its just pixels but with it comes a very unique experience that will shock you, piss you off, make your hands sweat and heart pump.

First, let me preface this: The majority of my time played is on PlayStation and Xbox, so that's where i put my time in.

 That being said, this game was once one of my most played games, always on my home screen, sitting there, waiting to be opened and played, but after Zero/Sam Fisher came out, the game became more and more try hard-y and less casual/fun, it became a game where, either you stomp on the THEM, or they stomp on YOU, which, i suppose is fine if you like really, and i mean, REALLY competitive play, but for the more casual gamer, you're going to get stomped into oblivion, and dare forbid you try anything other than meta, because you''ll get flamed by your teammates, and possibly be tk'ed, and the sad part is, i'm not even talking about the actual content yet.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The content in this game is...adequate at best, atrocious at worst. 

starting from:

-The Good:
the overall movement/gadget controls are simple, yet good.
Shooting is responsive, but i'll get more in-depth on this topic soon.
Diverse CHARACTERS, (you'll find out why i made this in caps in a bit.)

-The Meh:
The sound design,( again, more on this later.)
The maps are kind of a hit or miss, and you'll probably only get the ones that are bad more than good.

-The Bad:
The balancing in this game is pretty garbage, you'll only see people with two or three different guns, because the rest are either, too situational, or just plain bad, And some operators that are just plain broken, like mute, he can disable ANY electronics, and the really only 2 counters are, Thatcher and Twitch, Thatch being the hard counter, Twitch being the soft counter, as most GOOD mute players, will hide them where you can't really see them from drone holes, or they are too far for Twitch to do anything without getting in range of the mute jammer.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Operators are pretty diverse themselves, but, the GADGETS are whats the problem, they are so similar they might as well be the same thing, take Kaid and Bandit for example, they almost have the EXACT same gadget, the only real difference is Kaids' is able to position itself anywhere, and have a radius/AOE, see what i mean? it's all just copying another's gadget, but changing it a little bit, and then calling it a "revolutionary new gadget". Don't even get me started on the recoil either, you're either shooting people with minimal kick, or are up to the moon by the 2nd shot. I used to play Jager CONSTANTLY, he was by far my fav op. But not because of the gadget, But because the recoil was actually in a good state. It felt like i was actually Controlling the aim, But now his recoil is absolutely HORRENDOUS, for example: i was in a match recently where, there was a target about, 20-ish feet away, i shot at his chest ONCE, and my sight was up to forehead level, the funny thing is, I WAS ON PC, where most people are THE MOST ACCURATE WITH THEIR AIM.  I just couldn't fathom that every time i would shoot anything other than a little baby SMG, i couldn't get more than 4-ish shots in before i had to COMPLETELY recenter my cross-hair.

The sound design this game has is...ok i suppose, but one thing i can't understand is, WHY THE DEV'S THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO MAKE TEAMMATE'S FOOTSTEPS LOUDER THAN ENEMY'S. It's just plain annoying when all i hear next to me is "THUNK THUNK THUNK" from my teammates, while the enemies are like "tink tink tink".

All in all, the older version was WAY better than what it is now, which is the case for a lot of games nowadays, which is quite sad, but, old siege will always have a place in my heart. As one of the most fun games. It's sad to see it turn to this. One of my personal additions would be to add a game mode called, "Throwback". Old ops, Old maps before their rework, and basically reverting the changes back to early siege, before all this new shit.


TL:DR, Siege turned from goofy fun-having, to, a sweat swamp, horribly balanced, dust-collecting game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. This game is a huge hit or miss. I personally love this video game, I have played this game on the PlayStation for hundreds of hours but with the amount of unfair matchmaking this game creates for you, can make a very unbalanced and not a very fun experience. We can talk about Newcomer for a second, this mode is specifically for the players that are trying to get into the video game, and it's unfair to the players in there when a team full of smurfs come along and just ruin your fun. This game also have a very huge problem when it comes to skin prices. For example, if you wanted an elite skin for Thermite or Jaguar, have fun spending over $26 bucks for a singular skin, calling card, and victory emote. Not worth the spending of hard earned cash. The game is overall very fun and tactically balanced, but this game has a lot of issues.

An excellent team shooter with a fast time to kill and much to learn, but there's a few things that spoil this experience and make it incredibly hard to get into as a new player:

* The defender ability to run outside of site nearly consequence free.
* The defender ability to peer outside from inside site nearly consequence free.
* Various forms if pixel peeking, which isn't too much of an issue in most games, yet in this one you can make your own pixel peeks, which makes most memorization impossible, which otherwise would be possible in other games such as CS:GO.
* Shields are STILL nonviable competitively and able to be shot through from the front, due to bugs in the character animations which causes them to clip parts of their body through the shield, which has been a bug in the game since launch in 2015. It's been 7 years.
* Egregiously fast leaning/unleaning times allows players to leanpeak a corner and pre-fire an angle while fully protected nearly consequence free. As a player on the receiving end of this tactic, there is very little you can do to protect against this other than remaining incredibly mobile, which as it turns out is the competitive meta in this game. There is no place in high-ELO for slow players or angle-holders.
* 80% of skins and worth-while cosmetics that are not retextures are locked behind time-locked battlepasses, events, or $15 pay walls. If part of your goal as a player is to unlock cool character/gun skins, look elsewhere. Hunt Showdown, a game based in the year 1895, has better looking gun and character skins that are more achievable than anything you'll see in Siege.

R6 has became a very controversial topic.
If you're more of a veteran who played in the games prime, you'll know its slowly falling off grace more and more, many can agree it's not the same game as years prior when the competitive side of siege wasn't so forcefully integrated within the whole player base and people could choose how they want to play the game, as of right now it has been very heavily influenced by the E-Sports side and consequently many players left due to the harsh changes of many parts of the game.

Ubisoft is trying to somewhat revive the game but everything they do seems like a worse decision than before, straying it further from it's former self while also pushing more players away from the game by once again mentioned changes so heavily influenced by Pros. If Ubisoft want to make this game more enjoyable for everyone, they should not only step down from making such dramatic changes and/or get another smaller studio to have a fresh start for R6 for the companies and communities sake.

Overall the game was great and i would say revolutionary for FPS shooters, many hours spent with friends messing around and getting better, but at the current state of the game i don't think i would ever return as it would only hinder my opinion of Rainbow Six Siege even more.

Horrible competitive experience. Ubisoft Connect must be one of the worst game launch apps out there right now. 
Even with immaculate internet quality, Ubisoft repeatedly decides to disconnect from the server for no apparent reason. In competitive this translates into a game penalty which has led me to have a total ban time of 2 days just because of that consistent disconnect with the Ubisoft platform. 
The battle pass is too expensive, however the operators can be obtained by progressing through the game by playing regularly. 
The community in the competitive aspect is varied; but most of the times it is usually toxic. I have early Parkinson's, therefore my ability to play competitive games is not always optimal, and despite this I have a superior performance in competitive games; this game is very demanding in every aspect and in the competitive community, if you don't meet those standards, it's often reflected in an excessive amount of toxicity, team killing, and a ton of other forms of grieffing.

In conclusion;
The game is recommended for users who want to enjoy the unique genre that is R6S, But at the cost of having tolerate with Infinite of hackers, cheaters, constant disconnects from the game And other types of verbal aggression by other users.

I mean Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is good, but not quite as good as Cinnamon Pull Apart Bread!

What you'll need:

- A goofy ahh nonstick pan
- Non Stick Spray
- 2 Tubes of Biscuits (Pillsbury or Otherwise)
- A social security number
- 1 and 1/2 sticks of Salted Butter (Unsalted also works, just be sure to add a 1/2 teaspoon of salt in step 3)
- 4 Teaspoons of Brown Sugar
- 1 Teaspoon of Cinnamon
- 1 Tablespoon of Honey
- 2 Tablespoons of Milk, Heavy Cream, or Buttermilk (Non-Dairy Milks work as well. See Step for more info) (More as Needed)
- 2 Cups of Powdered Sugar (more as needed)

Step 1. Preheat your oven to 350 and give your pan a light coat of non-stick spray

Step 2. POP THEM BISCUITS OPEN BABY!!

Once you get the biscuits out, grab a butterknife (or use your hands you filthy animal) and quarter them. Start laying em out in the pan. Spaces in-between the biscuits is A-okay cause we want that buttersugar to get down in there once we start pouring. Likely, you'll run into the issue of "too many biscuit pieces, not enough space" so just kinda squish em down and try to fill in the edges and corners with an extra biscuit piece. Once you've got all the biscuits packed in there, we're on to step 3!

Step 3. BUTTERSUGAR TIME

Grab your 1 and 1/2 Sticks of butter and we're gon' melt that son of a gun. Personally, I like to melt butter in the microwave, but if you wanna get all fancy and pull out the saucepan then go for it. Ain't nobody stopping you.

So for the rest of us common folk, put your butter in a microwave safe bowl or Pyrex measuring cup. I throw it in there for like 1min and just check on it closer to the minute mark, but we all got different microwaves. Basically, you just want the butter to be melted with no chunks left in it. So however long it takes to do that. DON'T leave it in too long or it'll burn and then you gotta go get more butter.

NOW. You've got your melted butter. Add the Cinnamon and the brown sugar to it and stir the everliving life outta that thing til' it's all nice and pretty. Once you've successfully crafted the buttersugar, pour it over the biscuits in the pan. My two main goals here are "1. Make sure every biscuit gets some love" and "2. Fill in all the cracks" So pour slow and steady.

Step 4. MAKE IT HOT

Okay. Let me level with you here. I am not a classically trained baking professional. I'm just a regular schmegular person who likes the sweety sweets. I have messed these up before and this is the step that made my dad leave. And why did he leave? I ran out of milk.

Double check the oven is on 350. Put the little biscuits in the oven so that they can grow up to be big and strong. Leave them in there for about 10-13min. Be sure to check on your biscuits throughout the process. What you're looking for is the tops to be golden brown. Like that real fresh baked brown, that you see in the movies and tv and recipe sites. Once you see golden brown, open the oven and don't be afraid to get a little greedy. Grab a biscuit off the top so you can see how the middle section and bottom of the pan look.

If it looks doughy Turn the oven off and let the biscuits sit inside for maybe 5 minutes. Again, note the color of the tops and go back to your reference piece that you took out. You want them to look like done biscuits. I can't put pictures but I'll make a guide if people are interested and go back through all the steps with pictures.

If it doesn't look doughy Well then what the heck are you doing? Move on to the next step champ! We got biscuits to eat!

Step 5. Make the Glaze

In a good sized bowl, whisk together your Powdered sugar, honey, and milk. If you don't have a whisk, that's fine. Just go grab a utensil or something. Personal preference: Fork. They look meaner than the other utensils.

NON-DAIRY MILK USERS UNITE!
I really like an almond milk substitute here, but whatever works, works. Just know, with the amount of ingredients we're using here, your glaze may come out thin and runny. If it does, don't panic and cry. Just add a little more powdered sugar in tablespoon increments. Add, whisk and repeat if it still comes out runny. Once it's thick enough, go ahead on.

Take your goofy ahh mixture and and drizzle it over the finished biscuits. And boom done.

It's one of the games i've played the most, and had the most fun with, but over the last few years it has steadily been losing its personality, losing its creative gameplay, and ultimately losing the fun as well.

While overpowered characters are cracked down on, quirky wildcards and hit-or-miss character abilities are scrapped and replaced for just another wall breaker or area denial.
The things that made the game immersive and unpredictable are being stripped away every other patch. One step forwards, two steps towards becoming a generic corridor shooter overly tuned to professionals only.

I've played this game A LOT. 1,200 hours may not seem like a lot to some of y'all out there, but it's by far my most played game, and that's for a reason. It's simply, a lot of fun.

Rainbow Six Siege has an amazingly good blend of strategy, teamwork, and action to a level that I haven't seen in any other FPS game. Some others come close, but just don't quite hit the mark.

The game overall feels good. Controls are solid, shooting feels good, options are pretty good too. Graphics are pretty good, but honestly, the graphics aren't the focus in this game.

The strategy has evolved over the years with this game, the meta strategy is always different every time I pick it back up. But, the teamwork, is what will make or break an attack or defense strategy, and that makes this game very intense, and of course it can get heated sometimes. That's ok though, in my book.

The biggest con with this game, is definitely the cheaters. The cheaters have absolutely ruined Rainbow Six Siege after it became very popular. Now, it seems Ubisoft is making some attempt to put a stop to cheating, and Make Rainbow Great Again. I added up the totals they claim they've banned since Dec '21, and it was around 50,000 people.... yes, you read that right FIFTY THOUSAND CHEATERS. After starting to play it again, after not playing it for around 2 years, it's fun again, and I haven't had any cheating experiences so far. So now, I think I'll finally write a review for this game, and give it the credit it deserves.

So, why do I not recommended this game?

Shortly, "Ubisoft".

If that doesn't explain it, buy this game and play it on a competitive level. After a few matches you will realise and come across people that are either smurfs (main account is on a platinum level or above) or cheaters.

So to elaborate on the "Ubisoft" bit. Even tho Ubisoft apparently filters and bans players, i don't think they do this effectively. You might report a cheater through their website by opening a ticket, providing images, videos, but all they can say is "we cannot discuss with you the details of the investigation". This is so unrealistic and just bs so they can ignore the reports as long as they want. The sad truth is, they don't care about player reports; anti-cheat system either bans players or not.

Also, I cant get over the fact that the server all of my mates and I played ranked on crashed for god knows what reason, and we got 1-2 weeks ban with a lovely -50% renown boost. Reported it, nothing happened :) Apparently they can not compensate players (lemme tell you a secret, my mate had an active booster while the game was undergoing some maintenance, he opened a ticket and got a new one because he couldn't use it all, so honesty means nothing).

On the other side, so i'm not just all negative about the game. The game mechanics are amazing and one of the best tactical fps game. So many operators, so many gadgets, so many unique abilities and updates. The weapon customisation can help with accuracy a lot, which means it worth spending some time on testing those out.

Overall rating, solid 6/10.
Would recommend playing with mates or playing quick matches, but not on a competitive level as it is ridiculous.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single simp to Ela, who has a 140 pound ass now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Rainbow Six Siege. 
The game, that I wanted to play since it got released. But I had no PC. Now I am so happy to have one and it's compatible with this game! 
What do I like in this game?
1. The experience is very awesome
2. The GamePlay is hard for beginners like me, BUT that just gave me more motivation if I got a kill or won the game by myself. 
3. It's Realistic. (average things)
4. It's not Pay-To-Win (I mean the abilities aren't that important to win only with it)
5. It makes me fun. (The most games makes me bored after an hour or less)
6. Sometimes it's funny
7. The Anti Cheat system is very good. (Thumb up for BattleEye)

And yeah I think I have much more positive things to say but there's also negative aspects.

1. beginners have hardly a chance to play
2. Some things won't function smoothly
3. You dies too fast (it's not negative to me but beginners)
4. One Situation mission has a problem: The enemies won't spawn. Idk why, even after I run through the whole map.
(there's some more but idc them)

INGREDIENTS
2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)
1 medium yellow onion ($0.37)
3 cloves garlic ($0.24)
1/2 lb. carrots ($0.49)
1/2 bunch celery ($0.83)
2 split chicken breasts, bone-in ($6.64)
1 tsp dried basil ($0.10)
1 Tbsp dried parsley ($0.15)
1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)
1 whole bay leaf ($0.15)
Freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)
2-3 tsp salt ($0.05)
6 oz. egg noodles ($1.00)
INSTRUCTIONS
Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion, garlic, and olive oil to a large pot and sauté over medium heat for about 5 minutes, or until the onions are soft and transparent.
While the onion and garlic are sautéing, wash and slice the carrots and celery. Add them to the pot and continue to sauté for a few minutes more.
Pull the skin and any excess fat from the chicken breasts. Add the breasts to the pot along with the bay leaf, basil, parsley, thyme, some freshly cracked pepper, and eight cups of water. Cover the pot, bring it to a boil over high heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for one hour. Make sure the pot continues to simmer for the whole hour. If the heat is turned down too low and it is not bubbling away, the chicken will not shred easily.
After an hour of simmering, remove the chicken from the pot. Using two forks, pull the meat from the bone and shred it slightly. Season the broth with salt. Begin with one teaspoon and add more to your liking. I used 2-3 teaspoons. The flavor of the broth will really pop once the salt is added.
Add the noodles to the pot, turn the heat up to high, and boil the noodles until tender (about 7 minutes). Return the shredded chicken to the pot. Taste and season again with salt if needed (I didn’t need to). Serve hot!

There was once a time when me and my friends would play Siege for hours on end going over the nearly endless strats for each map and objective. Over the years the game has slowly lost it's originality also it's not the only good tactical shooter on the market anymore. Maybe I am just nostalgic and a bit biased towards the "Good Old Days" but as someone who has played this game for about 1500 hrs I don't find the urge to return and play more than 1-2 matches, cause I feel like it lacks the strategical depth it had earlier, careful planning and co-ordination has been sacrificed a bit in favour of raw aiming prowess and fragging out on your own. Also over the years the roster of playable operators has become more and more convoluted with each new operator and gadget becoming less and less original.

Having said that it is still a good game and is still a bit different that other run and gun shooters on the market, also though Ubisoft gets a lot of shit for their degrading graphics and monotonous quests they have continued to support the game and will probably continue doing so in the future, a no-brainer for people who like playing multiplayer fps games.

Overview: Quandale Dingle is an African-American man aged 20-25, most well-known for various unlikely and even seemingly impossible appearances throughout the entire universe, including virtual spaces. Another important piece of controversy regarding him is his imprisonment and eventual escape with the help of his friend Juandale Pringle.

Unique Facial Features: Quandale has an abnormally shaped nose, having a large size and pointing forward. His face is slanted downwards at an extreme angle, this being accentuated by his large lower lip.

Crimes and Imprisonment: After his incarceration, for battering on a police officer, grand theft, declaring war on Italy, and public indecency he publicly stated that on March 28th he will be escaping prison and has plans to "take over the world". Shockingly, even after this statement, he was still able to escape on the specified date due to the prison staff's negligence.

Escape from Prison: On March 28 2018, Quandale Dingle escaped prison and went into hiding at his friend Juandale Pringle's house. While he was running from police, he fell and accidentally scraped some foreskin off from his genitalia. Armed forces were later sent to Juandale's house, who was arrested and later killed. Quandale esecaped and is now staying at Aden Dookie's crib with Quindavious Gooch.

Family: It is known that Quandale Dingle has an autistic son as well as a "baby mama" named Sheniqua Anderson. His son's name is currently unknown. Quandale has stated that he supposedly gave away his son to "creepy old guys" due to his refusal to pay child support, although it is unknown if this is true. He has also stated that he trapped his son's hand in an air fryer. His relationship with his father is described as abusive by Quandale, who says he was "given a sucker punch full force" and was "smacked in the back of the head with a steering wheel" Quanlingling Dingle is Quandale's asian brother. At one point he placed illegal substances in Quandale's meal as a supposed assassination attempt or a misguided prank, which almost killed Quandale. Quandale's cousin, Henry Bartholomew Dinglenut was also arrested, for planting 2.5 Kilograms of TNT in a daycare center. Also putting a camera in president Joe Biden’s bathroom to watch him take a poo. His relationship with his mother, Quandlisha Dingleberry, is not in a good state, with her being the original founder of the AQTF, an organization with the goal of combating his devious activities.

Appearances: - Union city, New Jersey - New Batman movie (as "The Dingler") - Los Angeles - The lost city of Atlantis - The White House - Plushtrap Room (Five Nights at Freddy's 4) - "Prison Break" Roblox game - Lil Minion's mansion - Robbery of Goofy Ahh Jersey bank - Fortnite - Tilted Towers - Hitler’s Grave - etc.

Not the best R6 game at all because it focus on MP,

It's going to be a long story so just read me out.. but sure the MP is fun, got me hanging after the existence of Extraction... Then the game is a joke now to Tom Clancy's, seriously zombies? Ubisoft you need to stop taking acid and make a proper Tom Clancy's tactical shooting games again, and to me the last of the best R6 game was Raven Shield. Why? 

Because it's a Single Player, then you can build up your spec ops team from Alpha to Charlie team. After that you can make an infiltration plan on each team, you literally building your own gameplay style on the mission. The best thing about it is that, when you have casualty in your team, you can't bring them back and the spec ops will be lesser. That what makes me wanna redo the infiltration plan and make it better until each of them got out alive. 

The game is really unforgiving, you can die easily if you don't react quick before the enemies, even if you turned on the auto-aim. Now that's what i called a tactical shooting game, you really need to be smart, strategic, quick and, precision with the plan. But of course there's a flaw too, the AI can be really annoying and dumb sometimes, but there's an AI improved mod that you can download on the website which is A MUST HAVE before playing it. 

Then there's Vegas where the downfall start, everything is scripted focus on story, all of the sudden your teammate betrayed you in vegas 2 if i remember correctly kinda funny thou. Also no more team buildup, only you with your 1 team, no more infiltration plan, you can take much of the bullets and still be alive. 

i hope nothingless from ubisoft now, they've ruined Tom Clancy's this is for you Ubisoft

This game has stuck with me for a while. The game was at it's peak during 2017-2018 and It was Operation White Noise, and Operation Chimera. Those two Operation's blew the game up with the new map Tower, and especially with the "Outbreak" Event running from March 6, 2018 - April 3, 2018. Playing the game with friends then was extremely fun and even running solo was very fun at times. But if you were too play now the game feels boring without friends. The game rapidly decreased in player base around the end of Operation Neon Dawn and it was because multiple people in the community passed around that Ubisoft was running out of ideas and were making the game a little too much on the competitive side. Many people also complained about the recoil changes, the optic additions, the TOS additions, and the new UI. I do agree that most of the changes that were recently made to the game made it worse, but it is still Rainbow Six Siege and it is plenty of fun with a group of 4 friends on your side that don't focus on the game too much and are just there to have fun and blow each other up. But unfortunately Ubisoft is making a heavy change to team killing  as well so you can't blow up you're friends as much as you used too anymore. I'm glad I played during somewhat of a peak moment for Siege and I will still call this game a great 5v5 shooter any day.

Despite playing for thousands of hours over console and pc i cannot recommend this game. Whilst it has its good moments, overall it's terrible. The game's stability gets worse with every patch, the anti-cheat is about as useless as a politician, and ubisoft never deliver on their promises for the game's future. Year 7 and we are still experiencing bugs and glitches from day 1, and cheaters are getting worse and more common. The game just continues to get worse and worse. Do not buy this game, maybe if you get it cheap or for free but even then, not recommended.

***NEWBIES*** this game is at least 50%, if not more, all about map knowledge. 
So don't beat yourself up if you're super lost and everyone is yelling at you over game chat (community can be toxic at times). Just mute the salty people and report them if they TK. Trust me there are a lot of people in the game that will back you up and want to help, so don't let one bad experience make you quit the game for good.

There are a LOT of maps to learn and a lot of small details in every one. It's going to take the average person until your siege level is at LEAST 55 before you really start recognizing map layouts and details on all maps - including room orientation, call outs, soft wall, hard wall, what should be reinforced in each site, common paths of travel, etc.. And then probably until 80 until you're actually comfortable with most maps and operators.

More tips:
-There are a lot of Diamond/Plat smurfs in newcomer that like to make new accounts and s*** on actual new players because it makes them feel good for some reason, so you're better off playing quick match.
-To learn maps faster, make your own custom games and run around in them.
-When you die, make sure you watch the replay so you know what cheeky angle the enemy was holding and then don't do what you did next time, or use it to your advantage when you switch sides.
-If you're not on cams, watch teammates. Look at the places they check as they sweep rooms. Watch the paths they take. Look at how they engage in gun fights and how they rotate around the map.
-Squad up with friends - being able to communicate and laugh in a discord can really improve the game experience, even if it's just one other person.
-Best way to really understand an operator is to play them, so take advantage when there are siege events that allow you to play whoever you want. Use this information to purchase your next operator with the game currency.

– 1 1/2 pints (3 cups) Real California vanilla ice cream
– 3 large eggs
– One 15-ounce can pumpkin
– 3/4 cup sugar
– 1 1/2 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice
– 1/2 teaspoon salt
– 2 unbaked 9-inch pie shells (not deep dish), fitted into pie pans (if not already) and frozen

DIRECTIONS:
Prep time: 25 minutes

Cook time: 45 minutes

Preheat oven to 425°F.

Meanwhile, set ice cream aside at room temperature to soften.

In the bowl of a stand mixer using the paddle attachment or in a large bowl using a hand mixer, lightly beat eggs. Add pumpkin, beating on medium-low speed until incorporated. Add sugar, pumpkin pie spice, and salt. If ice cream is still hard, microwave for 30 seconds at a time until softened. Add ice cream to pumpkin mixture, mixing until smooth. Divide mixture between pie shells and bake 15 minutes.

Reduce oven to 350°F and continue baking until a tester inserted into the center of the pies comes out clean, about 30 minutes.

Serve warm or room temperature.

Servings: Makes two 9-inch pies.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

There is a plethora of shooting games out in the world today. They come on virtually every platform from cell phones to Computers and Xbox’s. Many good games are overlooked for the more mainstream ones such as “Call of Duty” whose games are extremely popular but at best subpar. One of the best new shooters on the market today is “Rainbow six Siege”. One of many games in the Rainbow six saga, Siege is the newest addition to Tom Clancy’s brainchild tactical shooter series.  The game features realistic five on five tactical combat between two teams. One of the teams attacks, while the other defends. Rainbow six’s graphics are amazing for a console game and really has the power to immerse a casual gamer. Rainbow also has a perfect formula for mixing in futuristic gadgets with real counter terrorism style combat in small environments such as residential houses and large yachts. Every operator has there own special gadget to gain the edge in combat and trying to guess which operators the enemy team will use is crucial to survival. That being said, you do not make it very far in Rainbow six without some sort of team work and collaboration as opposed to shooters such as Call of Duty that have more of a “one vs. all” run and gun mentality. As the game is rated M for mature by the ESRB, You will need to be over eighteen to purchase it. The strong rating is due to blood, drug references, strong language and violence, which some parents may find okay for their children.

I've played most Rainbow Six games, and have played online since Rainbow Six 3 on the original Xbox.  It's been a consistently enjoyable series!  I picked this one up on a lark, looking for a relatively lighthearted shooter that wasn't as anal-retentive as Counter-Strike, for example, and it fits the bill perfectly.

A lot of people online say it's too competitive and challenging for a newcomer, and I'd beg to differ - that being said, I've mostly played "newcomer" matchmaking.  However, it's a simple and fun shooter, and the MOBA-style classes to choose from make it interesting without necessarily making it more complicated, in my opinion.

Overall, very fun, and good for short rounds as well as long marathons.

rainbow six, more like no rainbow, six

it stands out from your standard twitch shooters (even though it is something you have to factor in and definetly need in game) because of the multiple factors you have to keep into account when playing. Map knowledge, operator abilities, speed, cursor placement, recoil control, verticality, sound and Intel though cameras and callouts makes it a difficult game to master but definetly a fun experience to learn. 

Casual and New players can also find their place in the game due to the more accesible TDM mode and shooting gallery which allows players to test out recoil control and damage input withou the preassure of being in a actual match.

Even if you play it alone or with friends it definetly scratches that itch for a shooter game. Definetly recommend it. Specially since devs are keeping it updated with community feedback. (with both professional and casual players input)

This is the only game I think I'll write a review for. There is one thing that keeps Siege players coming back time and time again despite all of the wonkiness.

There is nothing else that gives the Siege experience.

This game is weird. It's frustrating at times, but at other times, incredibly gratifying. I don't know of many other games that have given me the same dopamine hit as randomly flicking and firing through a wall only to headshot someone at random. This game isn't for everybody. Matter of fact, I'd say it's one of the hardest games to get a hang of right away because of its uniqueness, but that is exactly what makes it enjoyable. The higher in rank one travels in Siege, the weirder the combat gets. It was definitely more fun when I was clueless, but Siege has such a charm that it keeps me coming back to play for another several hundred hours. Whenever I play, I just want to be better, and I keep striving to reach that "better-ness". If you can get past the weirdness of the game, and the fact that the characters have evolved away from "operators" and now look more like OC's, the game is incredibly fun. Does it have issues? Sure of course it does. I highly recommend it either way.

This is the first FPS game I've played. 

At first I felt only having 3 gamemodes made it a very limited game but I quickly realized there are a lot of strategies and fun to be had in 3 gamemodes. Furthermore, having only 3 (that are very similar) keeps the game simple. While it can still be confusing for newbies it is not AS overwhelming. It also helps a lot if you have a friend to show you the ropes. 

R6S has in-game training that has the potential to be extremely helpful- IF the bugs were fixed. I looked into reporting the bugs after experiencing 3 or 4 bugs and learned that Rainbow's bug reporting system is crap. One of the bugs someone had reported (that I had encountered) was closed because only 4 people said they could reproduce the bug and it closed it stating "Not enough players stated they could reproduce the bug." In other words, because not enough players actively test & report (singleplayer bugs at least)- they will never get fixed. 

But as long as you stick to multiplayer it is very fun.

One of the only FPS games I play nowadays, just gets better with every update. Probably will play this game for the rest of my life. Also, i'm very pleased with the recent inclusion of LGBTQ+ operators, and the crackdown on team kills and toxic players. This has made the game far more enjoyable. Thank you Ubisoft!

I have this game on Uplay, and have over 2,500 hours, and I am just about level 300. 

This is hands down the best FPS game out there. This game is different in many ways, the most important being the destructible maps which allow you to win by more than just gun play. There are also many traps and gadgets which enhance the gameplay experience. 

I should warn you though, this game has a very toxic community and very abundant cheater player base, which takes away from much of the fun the game once had (I had never encountered a cheater for the first 2 years I played this game). If a new anti-cheat is announced, I could see this game coming back full swing. Though you'll have no trouble getting into a game.

One-shot headshots. While this has been a hot topic as of late, it allows players the ability to easily win in any situation whether is 1v5, or perhaps better odds. Though be careful, as poor positioning can cause you to lose a 5v1. 

I love this game, and I know with time and commitment to learning the ins and outs of the craft which is a Rainbow Six: Siege player, you can too. 

Enjoy!

Played since Year 1 season 3. I remember when Cav had C4 lmao. I have always loved this game. Its a hard game to get into nowadays with all the toxicity, and people not wanting to teach new players cause they only want to dog on them for being "bad" at the game for not knowing things immediately like the map. If your entirely new to the game i recommend playing with friends that will teach you or your gonna have to deal with assholes who think they know better just cause they have 1 more kill than you, yet die every round at the start. Try and learn the maps in deathmatch, quickplay, or training grounds. It will help out alot, and have you not get so many teammates being mad at you for not knowing them. Expect to have a hard time in the start to get kills and clutch. Its a hard game to learn and has alot of operators to learn. Once you learn all the operators, and their abilities you should know most anything that could affect the round. It takes awhile but its a very fun and satisfying game once you get past the learning curve. Its not a "realistic" game in the sense that how abilities work, but there are a FEW mechanics that ground the game in its realness. So expect to be caught off guard by how things work together. Its not a perfect game, but it has come along way from where it started, i can tell you that from experience. Its in its best state currently as a design and program standpoint. There are issues with hackers right now, but every game nowadays has that issue. You will see a couple here and there, but dont let it discourage you. They are currently working on everything involving cheaters for the future, and legitimacy of the game as every game is. Its far from a dead game, and can only grow from now.

Firstly just want to say a lot of my complaints aren't directly only at siege amd are toward the industry as a whole. That being said, my main complaints are: Lighting changes which removed the more realistic feel to the game

The map and map pool changes that change and remove maps under the claims they aren't competitive but then the replacements are just as bad if not worse.

The "balancing" which is just Ubi speak for "We want to change shit so it looks like we are doing something even when we know this won't do shit to fix the complaints surrounding a given issue"

The lack of any kind of solution to cheaters amd griefers

The constant changes of art style, the ui changes, and all the other visuals that only exist to keep having something to show off during updates since they don't add nearly as much real content as the use to.

But the biggest thing that bothers me, the removal of features because either Ubi doesn't know how to fix an issue or because they claim not many use it. Examples being, throw back grenades, change firemode, the breach charges giving an indicator as to what is and how much it can be broken when placing. All the extra abilities they have removed that made operators special, yet they leave others with no consistency on why or when something is removed.

Do you wish for severe migraine?

A lot of modern-day 'realistic' FPS games struggle with enemy readability, with most players applying some sort of filter to help with the issue. This is one of those games. It absolutely ruins the experience.

It's a good game. The PvE is limited and mainly used for warm-up or training. The PvP is where the real action is. The community can be extremely toxic, but I've met some who are very friendly and helpful actually.
There is an option to block text and voice chat, so if the toxicity gets too much, you can always do that; however, you won't be able to hear or receive positive messages or callouts either.

Overall, I would recommend the game, especially if you have some friends to play with.

Rainbow Six Siege is a very well-made game, but there are many issues, with the community, and glitches/bugs. Originally, Siege was a game-changing multiplayer, with a fresh community and players ready to better themselves. Over the years, Siege has caught less traction in media, thus yielding a declining player count; tangential to the decline of Siege's popularity, the community has also become more toxic, unfriendly, and even dangerous to play with. The sum of these detrimental addends has created a game that is no longer fun, nor enjoyable for most players alike. The main issues are now cheaters and toxicity. Ubisoft has done very little to combat these issues, mainly deviating from helping the community with an Anti-Cheat system, but constantly focusing on patches/fixing smaller bugs. Notwithstanding, the community is still alive, with many great people and awesome players, but I believe that Siege is nothing short of a husk, something left of the great game that was ONCE Siege. With all said, I believe that new players CAN grow into the community, and CAN overcome many foibles, like the skill gap, and mixed and mainly toxic community et cetera. With everything WRONG pertaining to Siege, I believe the game will NEVER become mainstream, and an as-popular game henceforth, so I do NOT recommend buying/playing Siege anymore, as disheartening as that is (for some.) But by all means, if you are curious about buying the game, or even considering, take many aspects of the game's current state, in lieu of buying it blindly and idiotically.

This game is like your first love... you see her standing in the distance beautiful and gorgeous and you fall in love with her where time just stops at a standstill. Your heart racing and beating out of your chest. The only crappy thing that no one tells you when after time stops is when time starts again it picks back but only faster to make up for the time lost. You are stuck in a limbo, the same place, while everyone else moves around you carrying out their own lives happily, eventually finding decent jobs, and settling down with marriage and children. You on the other hand are still stuck in limbo land eyes stuck on the day when you first saw her... even though shes long gone.*

*been playing for 7 years alpha beta. When the game first game out woowee it was so fun trying to figure out strats with random people and bonding over a successful mission or when jumping out of windows to get kills wasn't a thing nor was spawn peeking. I remember playing house with bandit shot gun leaping out of masterbed and cleaning up the other team outside in the first year of siege it was fantastic. Another great expereince was meeting random friends from NY and climbing up in rank 5 stack hitting diamond before there was even charms to prove it. It was an amazing experience. Sure Siege is still fun like it used to be but if you didn't play back in the OG times you'll never know what it was truly like before it became a sweat factory.

Anyway thanks for reading. I hope you're doing well and having a blessed life. I don't know who you are but I <3 u.

This is probably my most played shooter of all time, but even i can't be biased against the terrible stuff this game does.

First, you have to unlock all of the characters, unless you get one of those fancy editions. if you buy the base game then unlocking all of the characters without just giving up and buying them might as well be impossible, after the 600 hours i have in this game i still have only barely over half of the cast, and they only increase in price.

Second, they do not have their updating priorities straight, pretty much every single update of this game they change the UI drastically for like no reason at all, and they recently added new knife animations, when there are pretty glaring bugs especially with the friend system. i swear they add more bugs per update than fix bugs. trying to get in a party with your buds takes like 5 minutes because some weird bug where the invites don't work, or you show up as "away" or even offline, and each time this happens everyone has to restart the game to make absolute sure that it'll fix it, and a lot of the time it doesn't. it doesn't help you have to go through ubisoft's yucky "ubisoft connect" bs.

Third, some of the characters aren't fun to fight or are sometimes just unfair, (which sucks more because you have to buy them), and i just wish they weren't in the game. yeah this point a bit more personal, but i think we can all agree that no one exactly enjoys fighting a clash or jackal.

It's sad because if it weren't for these 3 things then i would probably call this my favorite shooter, but it's just killed my enjoyment of the game, and i just wish i could call this a polished experience. but for now i can only reccomend this game if you aren't bothered by these things, i mean if it looks like you'd like it you probably will.

(and ubisoft, can you pwetty pwease make a new rayman game, it's all you need to do for people to respect you again like cmon legends was soooo gooood)

The game is a really well made Tactical-Shooter Experience:
Not only do you have to communicate with your teammates to be able to beat the opponent team, but you will also need Map-Knowledge, Operator-Knowledge and so on.

Coming into this game is probably the hardest part since there are many smurf accounts and you are a newcomer to this. So remember beeing confused and getting killed a lot in the beginning.
When you slowly start to get better, that will fade tho.

While having Shooter-Experience from CS:GO or other shooters such as Apex or TF2, you will have a advantage of the aim, but thats just a tiny bit of what you need to win.

Having good aim can definitely give you a huge advantage in Gun Fights, but if you dont know where you can get flanked from, you will be terminated too.

All in all, this game is not a game for total Shooter-Beginners.
It's great with it's continues updates beeing brought to the game and it's variety and difference to every other shooter out there. 

As someone said to Far Cry 3:"It feels like Skyrim with guns", this game felt like Valorant without Abilities.

(This is only my opinion to the game)

Have a great Day/Week or whatever you prefer.

Rainbow Six Siege.

The game undoubtedly has a feel of competitiveness. The weapons have a great feel to it and the maps are well designed. The idea of being able to destroy pathways into the way you want makes you feel like you have more control. There are a multitude of players (operators) to chose from each with their unique ability ranging from bear traps to night vision scopes; all contributing to the success of the team bit by bit. Skill is a huge factor of the game. It will take hours and hours of dedication to master your operator. However it is a fun experience. Toxicity is a problem, through every lobby one player with a mic trash talking every opposing player. Overall would recommend for a more competitive and strategic FPS fast-paced bomb game.

[h1]Updated review of this game and Ubisoft Support.[/h1]


I bought this game with the Year 2 Season Pass shortly after its release (a long time ago).

Downloaded the game. Started playing what felt like tutorial missions from "Situations" and changed some controls to my liking.

Played a few matches from "Terrorist Hunt" mode. Then started a "Casual" multiplayer game. The community seemed nice and all the missions and matches had ended normally. I was able to close the game without any kind of warnings / errors / bans or kick-outs.

Not long after that, I received an email from Ubisoft saying that I have been permanently banned for violating the "Code of Conduct". There was no mention of which part of the conduct.

Then I opened the game and it displayed a ban message for "multiple cheating offences" and locked out almost all of the features the game has to offer.

Unfortunately I had spent more than 2 hours just by playing those single-player tutorial missions from "Situations", so Steam rejected my refund request.

I contacted Ubisoft's customer support to know the detailed reason and their response was:

"This message is to inform you that following a decision from ourselves, we are no longer able to provide support to you. Any future cases you send will be reviewed and then closed, unless we deem support necessary. This extends to all our support services, and the chat system will no longer process you into the queue for assistance."

I have been playing so many games for the past 18 years and this is the first game I have been banned on.

This was my experience of this game, now it is up to you to decide whether to buy it or not.

[h1]I rate it Ubisoft out of Ubisoft.[/h1]



Anyways, I was determined to know the reason of the ban even though they had partially "Support-Banned" my account.
After nearly 1 year of fighting with Ubisoft Support, they have made some things clear:

1. They have admitted that I did not use any third-party programs or modified the game in any way.

2. They actually did say that they are not accusing me of cheating / being a cheater.
Because I did not cheat and they obviously can not or does not want to provide any proof of anything.

3. This part of the conduct got me permanently banned: "The following list of forbidden conduct gives examples of unacceptable behaviour, but should not be considered exhaustive."
Now to be clear, the line "should not be considered exhaustive" basically means that Ubisoft can ban you just for opening the game, if they want to.

4. When I asked them about the above loophole, their response was: "The game team are not liable to inform players of every action that can lead to a ban, as this is left to the player to make a fair judgement on what is considered fair use of the game."
I did say many times that I consider all of my actions in the game to be fair but they decided to just ignore it. I do not know which action of mine was considered an unfair use of the game by Ubisoft.

5. Most important of all, they said that my ban was a manual / enforced ban.
Not an automated ban by BattlEye or FairFight. Or any other anti-cheat system this game may have.
Which confirms again that I have not used any hacks / cheats in the game. According to them, automated false-positive bans can be lifted but "enforced" (manual) bans can not be appealed. Therefore, my first appeal was denied and their policy does not allow players to make a second appeal.

So, do I know the exact reason of the ban? I do not and probably never will. But that is all I could get out of Ubisoft Support and I believe these are more than enough to prove that I have not cheated in this game in any way.
Their excuse to not tell me the exact reason for the enforced / manual ban was:

"We do not discuss bans for Rainbow 6 Siege and are under no obligation to provide proof or investigation findings into your ban".

That was everything I could get from Ubisoft before their UK Team Lead decided to issue a full "Support-Ban" to my account:

"After careful consideration of your recent actions and interactions with support, we have decided to withdraw support for you. As a result, we will no longer respond to your cases and they will be closed".

That was followed by a threat of permanent deletion of my level 59 Uplay account that has 60+ games:

"If you continue to do this, one of the outcomes of our disciplinary policy is potentially an account termination".

I had been a huge fan of Ubisoft since its Prince of Persia series and later, the Assassin's Creed franchise. I have tons of very expensive collectibles and some really permanent things related to Assassin's Creed. I think at the time of the ban, my Uplay account level was 57, this was long before they made their profile leveling system laughably easy. This did not change their minds however, to make an exception. Here is the message from their UK Team Lead regarding this:

"I understand that you are clearly a very avid gamer and a longtime fan of Ubisoft. I appreciate that you have a high level of dedication to your account that I have only seen a small handful of players surpass, and I do commend you for that. Whilst I appreciate your dedication, I cannot make exception to any situation that has led to a permanent ban, this is not based on your personal circumstances, more the actions taken on the account."

Now I can no longer get help or support for any of my other Uplay / Ubisoft games and any issues related to my account. If you ask me if all this was worth it, I will say yes. I did my best to get to the very bottom of this issue but I am not fool enough to risk losing my account along with all my games which are mostly expensive editions of AAA titles. This was however, a very sad experience for me to say the least.

Anyways, as you can probably see, they have taken full advantage of their End User License Agreement (EULA) in my case.

They went full Ubisoft. Never go full Ubisoft.

Siege is an amazing game, and certainly one the best current multiplayer FPS game in existence. It has been one of the only modern FPS games that has gripped and sustained my attention for years, and I constantly recommend it to anyone who will listen. 

I would describe it as such:  It has great team based game play with a fairly high skill curve, and requires pretty intimate knowledge of maps, vantage points, and complex lines of sight, but it also works for people who simply have good game sense and strong shooting ability. Every match plays out differently, and you will always be caught of guard by the creative (and always sneaky) ways in which your enemies will get the jump on you.

There are a ton of unique operators to use and learn, all of which have their own unique weapon sets and gadgets, and every season one or more are added to the roster, which constantly shakes up the meta and allows for new and unique team compositions and strategies. No matter what changes occur, however, the core gameplay remains relatively unchanged and it is the solid foundation of the game that keeps people playing in such large numbers after so many years. There simply aren't any comparable experiences available, which makes Siege so valuable in a space taken up by battle royals and run-and-gun shooters like Call Of Duty. 

In fact, Siege still stands today- many, many years after its launch- as one of the most original, innovative, and creative FPS games of the last 20 years, and I have no doubt that people will continue to play it until something else comes along that can learn from its strengths and fix its few weaknesses. So far, nothing really has. I played Tarkov for a while, but I really don't like survival games, and starting over in an endless loop in a survival simulator has never been my idea of fun. There are some titles that seem promising in similar ways to Siege- Ready or Not, GTFO- but I have yet to play those titles, so I really can't say if they will or will not live up to the hype. And,  unfortunately, other team based shooters simply don't appeal to me from a game play perspective, and certainly not aesthetically, either (valorant, Overwatch, etc). 

As some background to see if perhaps you have similar tastes and would also like Siege: I grew up playing Unreal Tournament, Doom, Quake and CS 1.6, and since the glory days of FPS games, nothing ever really clicked for me like I wanted it to. For a while, Destiny 2 PvP was a favorite of mine, as it brought back that highly energetic, competitive arena-esque FPS feeling for me, but I didn't really care for the grind required to access weapons and gear/weapon slot items, so I eventually stopped playing it. There are also many "overpowered" skills/abilities and weapons in Destiny 2, which makes keeping up with the meta and adjusting playstyles something that you basically have to do with every change to the game. Siege has many changes, but the core gameplay is always the same, and it always requires you to have good game sense, know the maps, and check your corners. 

With all that being said, just play Siege. It's still a great game, it has a dedicated developer base and fan base behind it, and it doesn't seem to be slowing down at all. You can que up into a casual match in about 10 seconds on PC, and no matter what the outcome of the match, or what crazy team you get thrown in with, its always exciting, its always a way to build your skills, and you will eventually meet people you can click with who you can form real squads with later on if you want to try your luck against other skilled squads. 

For me, it will always be a 10/10 game, and nothing really comes close when it comes to modern FPS games. Talk to anyone who plays the game, and they will generally have mostly positive things to say. Sure, there are always people who spend all their time on forums, lamenting any changes to the game, or who live purely in nostalgia for "the early days" and talk about developers like they are the scum of the earth, but I have seen nothing but dedication and competency from the Siege team over the years ( Especially when compared to other developers and franchises who abandon their player bases entirely, put out entirely broken patches and updates, or simply shut down servers entirely in favor of forcing people to buy full priced sequels that are functionally the same game anyway). 

Anyway, see you when you come running down the wrong hallway and trip over a claymore while getting shot through a penny sized hole 2 floors above you.

TLDR: Predatory advancement system and gameplay that has only gotten worse since the release.
I used to own this game for console back when it first came out. I really enjoyed playing it. However the game has become predatory with its pay walls. If you are new to the game you will have no operators to choose from. They will all be locked behind point buys or pay walls. All of them. It takes 10,000 in game points to unlock one, just one, operator unless you are willing to pay real money to unlock them early. Maybe you're thinking you can just grind points in terrorist hunt or solo play to unlock an operator? You can, but one match will get you approx 35 points. So you will need to play 286 games before you can unlock just one of the operators. This would be ridiculous even if this was a free to play game, but its not.
Gameplay has changed drastically in the last few years since I played it. Customizing recruits (the only option for people that have not paid for another operator or play 286 games) is impossible from what I can tell. You get 3 base line weapons and 15 seconds to choose which you want, even in solo play. Select fire is gone, so no more engaging at range with a gun that'll be decent at close range as well. All these fancy high tech gadgets for the most elite operators in the world and they don't even get a selector switch on their rifles?
My limited multiplayer gameplay was full of toxic people that spend most of the match slinging racial slurs and griefing me for only being able to use a recruit.

***NEWBIES*** At least 50%, if not more, of this game is map knowledge. So don't beat yourself up if you're super lost and everyone is yelling at you over game chat. Just mute the salty people and report them if they TK. Trust me there are a lot of people in the game that will back you up and want to help, so don't let one bad experience make you quit the game for good.

There are a LOT of maps to learn and a lot of small details in every one. It's going to take the average person until your siege level is at LEAST 50 before you really start recognizing map layouts and details on all maps - including room orientation, call outs, soft wall, hard wall, what should be reinforced in each site, common paths of travel, etc.. And then probably until 75 until you're actually comfortable with most maps and operators. I'll give 15% to your own gun skills, 20% to team work and communication (call outs call outs call outs, people. Don't be that guy that just looks at memes after dying. Unless it's casual.), and 15% to your knowledge of the operators and ability to utilize their gadgets.

More tips:
-There are a lot of Diamond/Plat smurfs in newcomer that like to make new accounts and s*** on actual new players because it makes them feel good for some reason, so you're better off playing quick match.
-To learn maps faster, make your own custom games and run around in them.
-When you die, make sure you watch the replay so you know what cheeky angle the enemy was holding and then don't do what you did next time, or use it to your advantage when you switch sides.
-If you're not on cams, watch teammates. Look at the places they check as they sweep rooms. Watch the paths they take. Look at how they engage in gun fights and how they rotate around the map.
-Spend the extra few dollars to buy a version with some operators - it'll make game play more fun for you and you'll have an easier time finding operators that work best with your play style.
-Squad up with friends - being able to communicate and laugh in a discord can really improve the game experience, even if it's just one other person.
-Best way to really understand an operator is to play them, so take advantage when there are siege events that allow you to play whoever you want. Use this information to purchase your next operator with the game currency.

Thank you ubisoft for ruining a truly unique game (who's gap in the genre has yet to be replaced) so that you could cannibalize it into a hero shooter E-sport with low time to kill.
